detail.title: International Transport Infrastructure and Regional Economic Development

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: We evaluate how access to international transport infrastructure promotes trade and economic development. Exploiting the gradual unfolding of transcontinental rail freight connections between China and Europe, our empirical findings indicate increasing exports from connected cities, with positive spillovers to neighboring cities and other indicators economic activity. Not all products and cities are equally responsive to new rail export opportunities. We set up a multi-sector heterogeneous firms model with a rich specification of trade costs, in which firms optimize trade costs by choosing alternative transportation modes and routes. Leveraging a unique data set on trade flows between Chinese cities, we calibrate our model to discuss local welfare effects, relying on sufficient statistics that quantify changes in city-level trade costs. We also highlight significant spatial distributional effects of trade infrastructure development.

title: The Determinants and Consequences of U.S. Firms' Differences in Post-Pandemic Inflation Expectations
affiliations: SKEMA Business School

detail.title: The Determinants and Consequences of U.S. Firms' Differences in Post-Pandemic Inflation Expectations
detail.abstract: This study introduces a novel measure of inflation expectations among U.S. firms post-COVID, using large language models (LLMs) to classify expectations as transitory or persistent during the high-inflation period. The measure strongly correlates with established inflation indicators, such as the Consumer Price Index and Cleveland Fed estimates. We investigate the drivers of heterogeneity in these expectations, including sector, CEO age, geographical location, and labor market tightness. Our findings reveal that firms with older CEOs, located in regions with tight labor markets, were more likely to expect inflation to be persistent post-pandemic. Furthermore, firms expecting transitory inflation significantly reduced short-term borrowing and inventory, while firms with persistent inflation expectations increase capital expenditures. These results highlight the economic implications of heterogeneous inflation expectations, while providing a novel approach to measuring disaggregated inflation expectations.

title: Is it Time to Put a Moratorium on List Experiments for Domestic Violence Elicitation?

detail.title: Is it Time to Put a Moratorium on List Experiments for Domestic Violence Elicitation?

detail.abstract: Using data from over 24,000 respondents in the Norwegian Crime Victimization Survey, we conducted a double list experiment to measure domestic violence (DV). Both list experiments revealed a statistically significant decrease in reporting when including a sensitive DV item. This clear violation of the “no design effects” assumption is not only explained by floor effects. One possibility is that the results indicate a "fleeing" behavior whereby respondents try to avoid association with DV. Combined with the inherent power limitations of list experiments in many contexts, these results underscore the need for caution in employing list experiments to measure DV, even inlarge samples

detail.abstract: The present study and research aim to briefly analyse the development of the idea of realizing a circular economy in Bulgaria. A comprehensive review of the basic strategic documents developed in Bulgaria, such as a national strategy and an action plan in this direction, is made, by defining and analyzing the goals and objectives in detail. Examples are given to support the author's theses, as well as those that serve to support the conclusions and conclusions. The circular economy is examined in both planes as a revolutionary model or a model that exists and is being upgraded. The main emphasis is placed on the approaches and relevant sectors in which the principles of the circular economy can and are successfully applied. The development is supported by a project survey and statistical data from Eurostat. Bulgaria is significantly lagging behind in implementing the strategy and planned activities, which is a result of the political crisis of the last few years and the inability to elect a regular government. All this and a complex of economic and other social factors further complicate the situation and create obstacles to the implementation of the national strategy.

title: Mind the Income Gap: How Public Transit Shapes Labor Market Inequality

detail.title: Mind the Income Gap: How Public Transit Shapes Labor Market Inequality
detail.abstract: This paper examines the socioeconomic impacts of the Expo Line Phase II extension in Los Angeles, using a Difference-inDifferences (DiD) framework with microdata from the IPUMS USA database. I compare areas directly affected by the new transit line to adjacent control areas, focusing on changes in public transit usage, labor market outcomes, and indicators of gentrification. Results suggest a substantial increase in public transit usage and a significant decline in unemployment rates in treated areas relative to controls. Additionally, monthly rents rose significantly, accompanied by a modest increase in the share of college-educated residents, suggesting early signs of gentrification. Effects are estimated relative to a 2013-2015 pre-treatment baseline, and pre-trend validity is confirmed through a placebo regression using only pre-treatment years. These findings contribute to understanding how major public transit investments can reshape local labor markets and urban inequality.

title: Threshold Effect of Bioenergy Technology on Carbon Intensity in US and China: The Role of Capital Accumulation, Education and Inequality

detail.title: Threshold Effect of Bioenergy Technology on Carbon Intensity in US and China: The Role of Capital Accumulation, Education and Inequality
detail.abstract: Bioenergy technology holds significant promise for reducing carbon intensity and fostering sustainable development, yet its impact remains unclear. This article employs both a panel threshold model and a random forest model, analyzing data from the primary administrative regions in the United States and China to explore the threshold effects and regional heterogeneity of bioenergy technology on carbon intensity. In the United States, the impact of bioenergy technology on carbon intensity initially shows a positive effect, which later turns negative as per capita capital stock increases. The technology's inhibitory effect strengthens with higher levels of education but becomes insignificant as the Gini coefficient rises. In China, increasing per capita capital stock shifts the impact of bioenergy technology from negative to insignificant, while higher education levels enhance its inhibitory effect. The Gini coefficient, however, does not significantly affect the technology's impact. Additionally, these threshold effects exhibit notable regional variations. The findings provide valuable policy insights for optimizing the use of bioenergy technology to mitigate carbon intensity.

detail.title: Can Country Policy and Institutional Frameworks Reduce Global Inflation?
detail.abstract: The study investigates the effect of country policy and institutional frameworks (CPIFs) on global inflation while controlling for the rate of unemployment and economic growth rate from 2005 to 2023. The country policy and institutional frameworks examined are the economic management policies, social inclusion/equity policies, structural policies, and public sector management and institutions. The findings reveal that public sector management and institutions as well as social inclusion and social equity policy have a significant effect on global inflation. The results imply that the presence of strong public sector management and institutions lead to a significant decrease in the inflation rate while social inclusion and social equity policies lead to an increase in the inflation rate. The implication of the findings is that public sector management and institutions as well as social inclusion and social equity policies are crucial for the persistence of global inflation.

title: Zoning Reforms and Housing Affordability: Evidence from the Minneapolis 2040 Plan

detail.abstract: In December 2018, Minneapolis became the first U.S. city to eliminate single-family zoning through the Minneapolis 2040 Plan, a landmark reform with a central focus on improving housing affordability. This paper estimates the effect of the Minneapolis 2040 Plan on home values and rental prices. Using a synthetic control approach we find that the reform lowered housing cost growth in the five years following implementation: home prices were 16% to 34% lower, while rents were 17.5% to 34% lower relative to a counterfactual Minneapolis constructed from similar metro areas. Placebo tests document these housing cost trajectories were the lowest of 83 donor cities (p=0.012). The results remain consistent and robust to a series of subset analyses and controls. We explore the possible mechanism of these impacts and find that the reform did not trigger a construction boom or an immediate increase in the housing supply. Instead, the observed price reductions appear to stem from a softening of housing demand, likely driven by altered expectations about the housing market.

title: Environmental Federalism

detail.title: Environmental Federalism
detail.abstract: Sound governance is indispensable for sustainable development in a period of growing environmental challenges. The system of environmental federalism in India, whereby central and state governments cooperate to preserve the environment, is examined in this paper. It looks at how the Indian Constitution divides the several duties for environmental protection and what laws and court rulings have done to mold this intricate but cooperative system. The study reveals some important prospects, for example the ability for distributed decision-making that fits the very varied local ecosystems of the nation. However, it also highlights some major issues, such as the regular overlaps of jurisdiction that can impede what should be seamless paths for decisive action and the necessary clear fiscal picture for any effective federal effort. This paper adds to the current debate on Indian federalism

title: Designing Scale-Sensitive Risk-Sharing Models for Financing Green Hydrogen in India
affiliations: Tyche Investments - Climate Consulting Group

detail.title: Designing Scale-Sensitive Risk-Sharing Models for Financing Green Hydrogen in India
detail.abstract:
The study aims to identify and evaluate fit-for-purpose, scale-sensitive risk-sharing models to mobilize private capital for both large-scale industrial and decentralized green hydrogen projects in India. In the context of high investment risks, technology immaturity, and policy fragmentation, the research seeks to inform the design of a financing architecture that aligns with India's National Green Hydrogen Mission (NGHM) and broader climate finance goals. This research employs a qualitative, desk-based methodology using secondary data sources. It analyzes global best practices, national policy frameworks, and institutional arrangements to develop a typology of risk-sharing instruments. A comparative matrix is used to evaluate applicability by project scale, while thematic coding informs a tiered de-risking framework suitable for Indian hydrogen ecosystems.

The study identifies 12 risk-sharing instruments—including blended finance, PPPs, viability gap funding (VGF), sovereign guarantees, and results-based finance (RBF)—and categorizes them by their applicability to different hydrogen project typologies. It demonstrates that large-scale projects benefit from capital-intensive, sovereign-backed instruments, whereas small-scale and MSME-led applications require grant-based and performance-linked tools. Institutional coherence and policy predictability emerge as critical enablers for financial mobilization. This is the first study to offer a comparative typology of risk-sharing mechanisms tailored to India’s hydrogen sector, emphasizing scale-differentiated financial design. It proposes a four-tier de-risking architecture aligned with investor risk appetites, project characteristics, and implementation capacities. The research bridges the gap between climate finance theory and operational investment frameworks for green hydrogen in emerging markets. The findings can inform policymakers, DFIs, and private investors in structuring blended finance vehicles, PPP models, and credit enhancement schemes. It provides actionable insights for agencies such as MNRE, SECI, NIIF, and SIDBI to anchor de-risking strategies and align India’s green hydrogen finance ecosystem with global climate goals and Article 6 mechanisms.

title: Markups, Markdowns, and Bargaining in a Vertical Supply Chain
affiliations: UMR SMART, INRAE, University Paris-Saclay, INRAE, AgroParisTech, Paris-Saclay Applied Economics, Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich (LMU) and University Paris-Saclay, INRAE, AgroParisTech, Paris-Saclay Applied Economics

detail.title: Markups, Markdowns, and Bargaining in a Vertical Supply Chain

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: This article bridges monopoly, monopsony, and countervailing power theories to analyze their welfare implications in a vertical supply chain. We develop a bilateral monopoly model with bargaining that accommodates upstream monopsony and downstream monopoly power. In equilibrium, the “short-side rule” applies: the quantity exchanged is determined by the firm willing to trade less. Welfare is maximized when each firm’s bargaining power exactly countervails the other’s market power. Otherwise, double marginalization arises in the form of double markdownization under excessive downstream bargaining power, or double markupization under excessive upstream bargaining power. We offer novel insights for price regulation and competition policy.

title: Impact of Super-Aging on the Monetary Policy Environment: Implications for Korea

detail.title: Impact of Super-Aging on the Monetary Policy Environment: Implications for Korea

publicationDetails.detailsText: Bank of Korea "Chapter 3 in Korea Economic Outlook (May 2025)"
publicationDetails.journalName: Bank of Korea Economic Research Institute Research Paper Series

detail.abstract:
I. The study analyzes how population aging affects the monetary policy environment and explores appropriate policy responses. As of the end of 2024, Korea has become a “super-aged” society with over 20% of the population aged 65 or older, and it is projected to have the highest elderly population share among OECD countries by 2045.

II. Aging is found to induce structural shifts in the monetary policy environment—namely, slower growth, lower real interest rates, and weaker soundness of financial institutions—which can narrow monetary policy space and exacerbate trade-offs between policy objectives when the foundations of growth and financial stability weaken simultaneously. The sectoral breakdown of these structural shifts is as follows:

• Slower growth and lower real rates: An open-economy life-cycle model for Korea shows that aging reduces labor supply, thereby lowering potential growth, and through reduced investment and increased savings, exerts downward pressure on equilibrium real interest rates. For example, if fertility and life expectancy had remained at 1991 levels (1.71 births per woman; life expectancy 72.2 years), the equilibrium real rate in 2024 would have been approximately 1.4 percentage points higher. Scenario analyses incorporating future demographic projections likewise indicate persistent downward pressure on both growth and real rates.

• Modest disinflationary pressure: Panel data analyses across OECD countries, combined with simulations for Korea, suggest that aging is projected to exert downward pressure on inflation of about a 0.15 percentage point per year from 2025 to 2070. However, offsetting upward pressures—such as deglobalization, supply-chain restructuring, and climate change—imply significant uncertainty about the long-term inflation trajectory.

• Weakened financial stability foundations: An analysis of panel data covering 7,148 banks over 27 years in OECD countries shows that aging tends to reduce banks’ capital ratios and increase default risk, driven by declining profits and subsequent pursuit of higher-risk, higher-return activities. Institutions with lending structures heavily concentrated in real estate exhibit larger negative impacts.

III. Structural shifts due to aging should be addressed through structural reforms in the real and financial sectors rather than short-term measures. Should the low growth trend persist, calls for accommodative monetary policy may intensify. However, low growth driven by structural factors cannot be effectively addressed by short-term, demand-side policies and such measures may entail side effects including financial imbalances. Therefore, a sustainable solution should be sought through structural reforms aimed at strengthening the fundamentals of the real and financial sectors.

IV. Specifically, structural reforms in the real and financial sectors should proceed as follows: To offset the decline in labor supply caused by aging, policies should expand female labor force participation and support continued employment among older workers. At the same time, improving youth employment, housing, and childcare conditions is necessary to encourage fertility recovery. To boost total factor productivity, policymakers should promote technological innovation and enhance the efficiency of resource allocation across the economy. Given that real estate–focused lenders are more vulnerable to aging effects, the current reliance on lending-based real estate financing needs to be gradually reduced. Additionally, in light of the financial market’s sensitivity to external price variables, the base of the demand for the Korean won must be broadened, and foreign exchange markets should be deepened to enhance stability and resilience.

V. These structural reforms are expected to raise real interest rates and potential growth, thereby expanding monetary policy space and reinforcing the foundations of financial stability. Scenario analyses indicate that, if three structural reforms are implemented—a gradual recovery in fertility to the OECD average, expanded employment among older cohorts, and a 0.5 percentage point increase in TFP growth—both real interest rates and potential growth will be approximately 1 percentage point higher on average during 2025–2070, compared to a no- reform baseline. Higher real rates would widen policy space and alleviate structural constraints on monetary policy; stronger growth would bolster borrowers’ profitability and soundness, strengthening the foundation of financial stability.

VI. In addition, efforts to enhance monetary policy effectiveness under the changed conditions should be pursued. These include continued refinement of the environment for open market operations to better reflect aging-induced changes in the policy environment; improved policy communication to more effectively manage market expectations; the use of an integrated policy framework that combines multiple instruments to achieve policy objectives; and, in particular, stronger coordination between monetary policy and macroprudential measures to improve overall policy effectiveness.

title: On the Long-Run Effects of Multihoming in Platform Markets

detail.title: On the Long-Run Effects of Multihoming in Platform Markets
detail.abstract: Two platforms engage in an infinite-horizon competition in two-sided markets. A group of new consumers arrive each period and live for two periods, and "old consumers" form an installed base "one side," who interact with "the other side" formed by new consumers. We consider two regimes-the one where multihoming is allowed and the other where it is not-and derive a unique linear Markov perfect equilibrium for each regime. Multihoming allowance slows down the convergence to the steady state, but improves steady state total surplus, and this welfare-improving effect is higher when the platforms are more patient. Under certain conditions, the platforms prefer to restrict multihoming due to higher steady state profits, so the firms' incentives can be misaligned with the social and consumers' incentives.

title: Low-Rank Covariance Estimation via Randomized Singular Value Decomposition for Scalable Portfolio Optimization

detail.title: Low-Rank Covariance Estimation via Randomized Singular Value Decomposition for Scalable Portfolio Optimization
detail.abstract: Classic mean-variance optimization of investment portfolios relies on the accurate estimation of the covariance matrix of asset returns for optimization. However, in a high-dimensional setting, where the asset universe comprises hundreds to thousands of symbols, covariance matrices are frequently too noisy and ill-conditioned, often resulting in portfolios that underperform. This paper examines the application of randomized singular value decomposition to enable low-rank approximation of a high-dimensional covariance matrix, thereby improving the signal-to-noise ratio that supports optimization gradient methods.

detail.abstract:
This book, Silent Wheel of America profound economic contributions of immigrants who have shaped and continue to shape the American landscape. While the Statue of Liberty welcomes newcomers with its iconic promise, the reality for many immigrants is a silent struggle – a journey fraught with challenges, sacrifices, and unwavering determination. Their stories, often untold, are the driving force behind this work.

We often hear statistics about immigration's impact on the US economy, but those numbers rarely capture the human element. This book aims to bridge that gap. Through meticulous research, analysis of economic data, we will explore the multifaceted contributions of immigrants – from their tireless work in essential sectors to their groundbreaking innovations and crucial role in times of crisis.

The chapters will explore into the historical context of immigration to the United States, examining the patterns, challenges, and economic impacts throughout different eras. This isn't simply an economic analysis; it’s a social commentary. We'll address the policy implications affecting immigration and economic growth, examine the complex interplay of cultural integration and economic benefits, and discuss the critical issue of public perception and its influence on economic opportunities for immigrants. Also, we will highlight the unique experiences and contributions of immigrant women and explore the impact of immigration at both local and national levels.

This book is intended as a valuable resource for students and scholars across numerous disciplines including political science, sociology, finance, economics, Administrative science, Management, Immigration, Travel, History and statistics. Its comprehensive exploration of past, present, and future trends in immigration and its economic consequences offers a wealth of knowledge and insight. It is my hope that Silent Wheel of America will contribute to a more significant understanding of immigrants and its crucial role in the ongoing American story. It's time to strengthen the voices and acknowledge the enduring legacy of these unseen economic heroes.

detail.abstract: A B S T R A C T: The massive accumulation of coal gangue not only occupies large areas of land but also poses serious environmental threats. Using coal gangue for backfill reclamation offers an effective solution to these issues by enabling both land rehabilitation and solid waste utilization. This study investigates the regulation of rainfall infiltration by varying soil cover thicknesses through a combination of numerical simulations, laboratory soil column experiments, and field-scale infiltration monitoring.  Based on measured hydraulic parameters of soil and coal gangue, the water movement under both short-term and long-term rainfall scenarios was simulated using the Van Genuchten model. The results indicate that: (1) under extreme short-term rainfall, a 50 cm intermediate soil layer significantly delays infiltration, reducing interface moisture content by approximately 40% and effectively minimizing leachate generation; (2) although increasing the cover thickness to 70–100 cm further delays infiltration, the marginal benefits decline; (3) a stratified structure consisting of 5 m coal gangue alternated with 0.5 m soil layers, topped by a 1 m surface layer, facilitates smooth moisture transitions and reduces deep percolation under prolonged rainfall; (4) even under extreme rainfall conditions (50 cm/day), the system maintains hydrological stability; and (5) multi-objective optimization using NSGA-II suggests that a total soil cover thickness of 50–60 cm achieves a favorable balance between leachate control, economic cost, and ecological risk in both arid and humid regions.

detail.title: Decisions Without Execution: The Crisis of Effectiveness of State Administrative Courts in the Indonesian Administrative Law System
detail.abstract: Plato, through Politea and Nomos, offers guidance on the structure of legal order and state administration to adapt to changes within the community. Therefore, stakeholders, specifically state administrative officials should act according to their duties and authorities in line with applicable provisions (law in abstracto) and specifically comply with court decisions as concrete law (law in concreto). The compliance ensures the creation of legal certainty and justice. This study used a normative legal method through a literature review combined with a case study method focusing on the State Administrative Court (“PTUN”) in Mataram, Indonesia. The following study problems were addressed, namely (1) How effective is the implementation of the PTUN decisions in Indonesia in this case? and (2) What factors influence the ineffectiveness of the Court’s decisions implementation?. The results showed that the implementation of the State Administrative Court’s decisions was ineffective due to the absence of a dedicated executive enforcement institution, weak sanctions against disobedient officials, and a bureaucratic culture permissive of legal violations. The three factors emphasized that the weaknesses in Indonesian administrative law originated from the substance of the law as well as the institutional structure and the legal culture of a bureaucracy that did not comply with court decisions.

title: Sustainable Pilgrimage Corridor: A Case of Vrindavan
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Sustainable Pilgrimage Corridor: A Case of Vrindavan
detail.abstract: Vrindavan, a sacred town in Uttar Pradesh's Mathura district, holds immense spiritual importance in Hinduism as the legendary playground of Lord Krishna. Despite its global pilgrimage appeal, the urban environment of Vrindavan is under severe stress due to unmanaged religious tourism, unregulated commercial expansion, and fragmented civic infrastructure. Core precincts like the Banke Bihari Temple zone, Loi Market, Yamuna Ghats, and the 21-kilometer Parikrama Marg experience extreme congestion, sanitation challenges, and environmental degradation, especially during peak festivals. The absence of a coordinated urban planning mechanism has resulted in piecemeal interventions, compromising both spiritual sanctity and urban functionality. This study proposes a Comprehensive Pilgrimage Corridor that integrates sacred geography, pedestrian connectivity, heritage preservation, and ecological restoration within a unified governance framework. Anchored around the Banke Bihari precinct and extending to Nidhivan, Keshi Ghat, Rangji Temple, and other religious-spiritual landmarks, the project seeks to transform Vrindavan into a model of sustainable pilgrimage urbanism. Key features include the creation of a Special Purpose Vehicle (SPV) for coordinated implementation, rehabilitation zones for affected vendors and residents, smart mobility interventions, and financial models combining state, central, and private funding mechanisms. Drawing on successful case studies like the Kashi Vishwanath and Mahakal corridors, this initiative presents Vrindavan as a replicable model of spiritual urban renewal. It emphasizes inclusive stakeholder participation, heritage-sensitive design, and long-term ecological and economic sustainability. The proposal reimagines the sacred landscape not only as a devotional terrain but as an evolving urban form where spiritual experience, environmental responsibility, and community well-being coexist harmoniously.

title: Machine Learning-Assisted Photoelectrochemical Biosensor Based on In2o3@Znin2s4 Z-Scheme Heterostructures for Portable Analysis of Ascorbic Acid
affiliations: Anhui Polytechnic University, Anhui Polytechnic University, Anhui Polytechnic University, Anhui Polytechnic University, Anhui Polytechnic University, Anhui Polytechnic University, Southern University of Science and Technology and Anhui Polytechnic University

detail.title: Machine Learning-Assisted Photoelectrochemical Biosensor Based on In2o3@Znin2s4 Z-Scheme Heterostructures for Portable Analysis of Ascorbic Acid
detail.abstract: Photoelectrochemical (PEC) sensing is an emerging analytical technology prized for its high sensitivity, rapid response, and portability. Herein, In2O3@ZnIn2S4 (In2O3@ZIS) artificial Z-scheme heterostructures were synthesized via a facile in-situ epitaxial growth method. Thermodynamic and kinetic investigation of the charge transfer studies revealed that the In2O3@ZIS Z-scheme heterostructure significantly enhanced the photoelectrode's photo-generated electron-hole separation efficiency and light-harvesting capability. The optimized photoelectrode achieved a remarkable photocurrent density of 39.33 μA/cm², marking an 86.60-fold enhancement over pristine ZIS (0.454 μA/cm²). Leveraging this platform, a portable PEC detection system was self-constructed for the ultrasensitive detection of ascorbic acid (AA). The sensor demonstrated a linear response ranging from 10-7 M to 10-2 M with a low detection limit (LOD) of 29.9 nM. Furthermore, an artificial neural network (ANN) algorithm was employed to train 152 experimental data and generated a predictive regression model for AA. This model exhibited high accuracy (R² = 0.9984) and low prediction error (<10%) for the prediction of AA. This work provides a promising approach for high-accuracy, intelligent, and portable detection of AA.

title: Fuzzy, Intuitionistic and Neutrosophic Set Theories and Their Applications in Decision Analysis Editors

detail.title: Fuzzy, Intuitionistic and Neutrosophic Set Theories and Their Applications in Decision Analysis Editors
detail.abstract: This book explores the development and importance of these mathematical approaches in managing uncertainty and imprecision in decision-making, and focuses on the practical applications of these theories in decision-making, demonstrating how they improve uncertainty modeling and facilitate more effective decision-making across various fields. By leveraging these frameworks, decision-makers can better navigate complexity, leading to more accurate and dependable outcomes. Ultimately, it  highlights the progression from fuzzy to intuitionistic fuzzy to neutrosophic set theories as a significant advancement in capturing and analyzing uncertainty within decision-making contexts.

title: Does Exposure to POSHAN Abhiyaan Reduce the Risk of Malnutrition among Children Aged 6-23 Months: Evidence from High-Burden Districts of Malnutrition in India, 2019-21
affiliations: University of Delhi - Institute of Economic Growth (IEG) and University of Delhi - Institute of Economic Growth (IEG)

detail.title: Does Exposure to POSHAN Abhiyaan Reduce the Risk of Malnutrition among Children Aged 6-23 Months: Evidence from High-Burden Districts of Malnutrition in India, 2019-21

declarations.declarationOfInterest: Authors declare that there is no conflict of interest.

detail.abstract: Childhood wasting, underweight, and anaemia are major health concerns in developing countries, especially during the critical “First 1,000 Days” from conception to age two. India’s POSHAN Abhiyaan, launched in 2018, aimed to combat undernutrition among women and children through a multisectoral approach. This study assessed its impact on children aged 6–23 months in 315 priority districts using multivariate logistic regression and Propensity Score Matching (PSM). Results showed that children exposed to the programme had 25% lower odds of wasting, 13% lower odds of being underweight, and 24% lower odds of anaemia, though no significant effect was observed on stunting. PSM estimates confirmed a significant average treatment effect on the treated for these outcomes. POSHAN Abhiyaan’s success is attributed to innovations in service delivery, skill enhancement of frontline workers through the Incremental Learning Approach (ILA), and the use of digital tools like the POSHAN Tracker for effective monitoring and accountability.

title: Machine Learning for Timing: Evidence from U.S. and Chinese Stock Markets
affiliations: Guangdong University of Finance & Economics, Beijing Jiaotong University, School of Economics and Management, Hunan University and Xiamen University

detail.title: Machine Learning for Timing: Evidence from U.S. and Chinese Stock Markets
detail.abstract: This paper reevaluates the longstanding debate in finance concerning the relative importance of stock selection versus timing, in the context of the increasing adoption of machine learning and big data in asset management. Focusing on both the U.S. and Chinese stock markets, we propose a novel methodology that integrates machine learning for stock selection with price-based signals for portfolio timing. Our findings reveal that, across both markets, stock selection driven by machine learning methods demonstrates strong return predictability, whereas timing signals show limited efficacy, particularly when accounting for trading costs. We conclude that the marginal contribution of timing within a machine learning-based stock selection framework is relatively constrained, a pattern that is consistent across both the U.S. and Chinese markets. Additionally, our study delves into "learning from machine learning", examining the characteristic differences of portfolios constructed via machine learning and valuing the relative importance of various characteristics.

title: Swap Line Dollar Supply
affiliations: University of St.Gallen

detail.title: Swap Line Dollar Supply
detail.abstract: The lack of globally representative data on OTC FX derivatives has left the transmission mechanism of Federal Reserve swap lines to offshore borrowing rates only partially understood. Using a new data source based on worldwide settlement records, I uncover the swap line supply channel: non-U.S. banks temporarily park swap line liquidity with U.S. dealers in the interbank FX market, reducing dealers' inventory funding needs in times of stress and thereby leading to narrower effective spreads charged to the real economy. I develop a simple model of trading to show the observed dynamics reflect either precautionary liquidity hoarding or arbitrage by non-U.S. banks, and propose a testable hypothesis to distinguish between the two.

title: Optimal Policy Design for Teacher Recruitment
affiliations: University of Toulouse 1 - Toulouse School of Economics (TSE)

detail.title: Optimal Policy Design for Teacher Recruitment
detail.abstract: This paper studies the design of higher education policies targeted at improving teacher recruitment. I leverage the introduction of a policy in Chile that aimed to raise teacher quality by crowding-in higher performing students into Education programs, while crowding-out the lower-performing ones. Exploiting the sharp assignment rule I estimate that, at the threshold, enrollment of high performing students at teacher colleges increased by 42%, with low-income students coming disproportionately from non-enrollment. The policy generated a positive composition effect of 0.25SD in test scores, which lead to an increase in 0.11SD in Teacher Value Added and 0.12SD in Teaching Skills. I develop a general equilibrium model of the higher education market. In doing so, I present a novel method for solving discrete-continuous games in large markets. Counterfactual simulations show that alternative policies can improve the distribution of students that enroll in Education programs. The distribution of college quality limits the impact on Teacher Value Added, while Targeting the policy to low-income students can yield further gains at no additional cost.

title: The Personalist Penalty: Varieties of Autocracy and Economic Growth
affiliations: University of Chicago, Harris School of Public Policy, University of Chicago and Princeton University - Princeton University

detail.title: The Personalist Penalty: Varieties of Autocracy and Economic Growth

publicationDetails.detailsText: University of Chicago, Becker Friedman Institute for Economics Working Paper No. 2025-95
publicationDetails.journalName: Becker Friedman Institute for Economics Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: Studies of income and regime type typically contrast democracies and autocracies, ignoring heterogeneity in the character of authoritarian regimes. We focus on the consequences of personalist rule, where power is concentrated in an individual or small elite. Extending the dynamic panel strategy of Acemoglu, Naidu, Restrepo, and Robinson (2019), we estimate the differential growth performance of democracies, institutionalized autocracies, and personalist autocracies. Across eight GDP series, eight autocracy codings, and six measures of personalism, we observe a consistent pattern: Whenever an “autocratic penalty” emerges, it is concentrated in personalist regimes. The growth performance of institutionalized dictatorships, in contrast, is statistically indistinguishable from that of democracies. We document evidence that the “personalist penalty” is driven by some combination of low private investment, poor public-goods provision, and conflict. These findings emphasize the analytic payoff of unpacking autocracy and highlight the different incentives facing leaders with narrow and broad bases of power.

title: ЦИВІЛЬНА ОБОРОНОЗДАТНІСТЬ: МІЖДИСЦИПЛІНАРНІ ВИМІРИ НАУКОВОЇ ПРОБЛЕМИ (Civil Resistance Capability: Interdisciplinary Dimensions Of A Scientific Problem)
affiliations: Hryhorii Skovoroda University in Pereiaslav

detail.title: ЦИВІЛЬНА ОБОРОНОЗДАТНІСТЬ: МІЖДИСЦИПЛІНАРНІ ВИМІРИ НАУКОВОЇ ПРОБЛЕМИ (Civil Resistance Capability: Interdisciplinary Dimensions Of A Scientific Problem)
detail.abstract:
This article substantiates the necessity of scholarly development of the concept of “civil resistance capability” in the context of the full-scale and hybrid war waged against Ukraine. The relevance of the topic stems from the growing need to conceptualize the role of the civilian population in the architecture of national resistance and in ensuring the resilience of society under prolonged threats. The aim of the study is to formulate an interdisciplinary conceptual framework for this new term and to determine its semantic content, structural components, and its connections with related categories in the fields of social, behavioral, and security sciences.

To achieve the stated objective, the research applies methods of conceptual analysis, systematization, comparative-terminological review, elements of structural-functional modeling, and interdisciplinary synthesis. Particular attention is paid to the phenomenological exploration of psychological, sociocultural, axiological, and behavioral determinants of the civilian population’s resistance capacity.

The study proposes an original definition of “civil resistance capability” as an integrative quality of individuals and communities, manifested in the ability to offer conscious, motivated, and morally grounded resistance to an aggressor by mobilizing value-based, cognitive, volitional, communicative, and socio-organizational resources. Six basic structural components of the phenomenon are outlined: value-motivational, cognitive, emotional-volitional, social, communicative, and behavioral. An adaptive-mobilizational model of their interaction is proposed. The concept is distinguished from related terms such as psychological resilience, mobilizational readiness, self-organization, and resistance by examining its semantic capacity and functional designation.

The practical value of the results lies in the applicability of the proposed conceptualization to the development of legal frameworks, educational programs, psychodiagnostic tools, and strategic documents aimed at enhancing societal resilience and organizing national resistance effectively. The study’s conclusions identify prospects for future empirical investigations focused on the operationalization of the construct, adaptation of measurement methodologies, and integration of resistance capability into broader security policies.

title: Opacity as Authority: Arbitrariness and the Preclusion of Contestation
affiliations: University of Nantes - Faculty of Law and Political Science

detail.title: Opacity as Authority: Arbitrariness and the Preclusion of Contestation

declarations.declarationOfInterest: The author declares no financial or personal conflict of interest.
declarations.ethicsApproval: This article mentions and includes an appendix featuring an anonymized and altered excerpt of a human interaction, reconstructed solely for theoretical illustration. No formal ethics approval or written consent applies.
declarations.funderStatement: No funding was received for this study.

detail.abstract:
This article redefines arbitrariness not as a normative flaw or a symptom of domination, but as a foundational functional mechanism structuring human systems and interactions.
Diverging from critical traditions that conflate arbitrariness with injustice, it posits arbitrariness as a semiotic trait: a property enabling systems—linguistic, legal, or social—to operate effectively while withholding their internal rationale. Building on Ferdinand de Saussure’s concept of l’arbitraire du signe, the analysis extends this principle beyond language to demonstrate its cross-domain applicability, particularly in law and social dynamics.

The paper introduces the "Motivation → Constatability → Contestability" chain, arguing that motivation functions as a crucial interface rendering an act’s logic vulnerable to intersubjective contestation. When this chain is broken through mechanisms like “immotivization” or “Conflict Lateralization” (exemplified by “the blur of the wolf drowned in the fish”), acts produce binding effects without exposing their rationale, thus precluding justiciability.

This structural opacity, while appearing illogical, is a deliberate design protecting authority from accountability.

Drawing on Shannon’s entropy model, the paper formalizes arbitrariness as A = H(L∣M) (conditional entropy). It thereby proposes a modern theory of arbitrariness as a neutral operator central to control as well as care, an overlooked dimension of interpersonal relations. While primarily developed through human social systems, this framework also illuminates a new pathway for analyzing explainability in advanced artificial intelligence systems.

title: Assessment of Electric Vehicle Charging Service Improvement Priorities Based on Online Review Mining and Sd-Kano Model
affiliations: Sichuan University, Sichuan University, Shandong University - School of Management and State Grid Shandong Electric Power Company

detail.title: Assessment of Electric Vehicle Charging Service Improvement Priorities Based on Online Review Mining and Sd-Kano Model
detail.abstract: Under the background of the rapid development of the electric vehicle industry, charging service quality has become a critical factor constraining user experience enhancement and sustainable industry development. This study, based on user online charging reviews, constructs a charging service improvement prioritization model that integrates text mining, dual importance analysis and demand classification. Firstly, natural language processing and fine-grained sentiment analysis methods are integrated to systematically deconstruct service attributes in review texts and quantify their sentiment orientation values. Then, we design a neural network-Kano joint model, revealing the nonlinear driving effects of service attribute sentiment orientations on user satisfaction through a Backpropagation Neural Network incorporating an attention mechanism, simultaneously combining an improved Kano model for service demand classification, and ultimately generating a three-dimensional Sentiment-Driver-Kano (SD-Kano) decision matrix that integrates dual importance of service attributes (emotional expression intensity, satisfaction driving effects) and Kano types. Finally, an experiments demonstrates that this model can precisely identify the positioning and user perception characteristics of different service attributes, and proposes several targeted service attribute improvement priorities and resource allocation strategies. The research outcomes provide charging service operators with a scientifically rigorous and operationally practical decision-support tool for implementing differentiated resource allocation and service efficiency enhancement.

title: An Efficient Heuristic Algorithm for Stochastic Multi-Timescale Distribution Network Reconfiguration with High Renewables
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and North China Electric Power University

detail.title: An Efficient Heuristic Algorithm for Stochastic Multi-Timescale Distribution Network Reconfiguration with High Renewables

keywords.keywords: Distribution network reconfigurationMulti-timescaleStochastic optimizationModel predictive controlOptimal power flow

detail.abstract: To handle the uncertainties brought by the increasing penetration of renewable energy sources and random loads, we design a stochastic multi-timescale distribution network reconfiguration (SMTDNR) framework to coordinate diverse scheduling resources across different timescales and develop an efficient heuristic algorithm to solve this complex NP-hard combinatorial optimization problem efficiently. First, the SMTDNR problem is established, incorporating distributed renewable generators, fuel generators, energy storage systems, and controllable loads, simplified through circular constraint linearization, Jabr relaxation, and second-order cone (SOC) relaxation techniques. Then, a one-stage multi-timescale successive branch reduction (MTSBR) algorithm is developed for distribution networks with one redundant branch, which transforms the SMTDNR problem into an SMTOPF problem. This is extended to a two-stage MTSBR algorithm for general networks with multiple redundant branches, which iteratively runs the proposed one-stage MTSBR algorithm. Numerical results on modified IEEE 33-bus and 123-bus distribution networks validate the superior optimality, feasibility, and computational efficiency of the proposed algorithms, particularly under high renewable penetration and increased uncertainty scenarios, offering robust and feasible solutions where traditional methods may fail.

title: Factors Influencing the Success of Smart Construction Technology
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN and Korea Aerospace University

detail.title: Factors Influencing the Success of Smart Construction Technology
detail.abstract: The construction industry is introducing smart construction technology to improve productivity and ensure the safety of facilities. Smart construction technology has not spread as much as expected due to the rigidity of the traditional production system, and this study aims to analyze and present the factors affecting the success of smart construction technology. A research model was established to reflect the characteristics of smart construction technology based on the information system (IS) success theory and the technology acceptance model (TAM). An empirical analysis was conducted through the responses of 199 people surveyed online and offline for construction industry workers. It was found that variables that affect the usefulness include connection quality, systems, and services, as well as user innovation. Smart construction technology infrastructure and users' innovation and usefulness have been found to affect their intention to use, and intelligence, service quality, and user innovation suitable for field characteristics have been found to affect ease of use. Factors affecting the performance of smart construction technology were found to be both usefulness and intention to use. The results of this study confirmed a causal relationship model that explains the factors influencing the success of smart construction technology. The results suggest that smart construction technology policymakers need to establish and implement policies for the parallel development of surrounding ecosystems to lead the development of smart construction technology. Smart construction technology development and sellers need to develop incentive programs that encourage users' innovation. It was confirmed that the expansion and development of the surrounding ecosystem were necessary for the success of smart construction technology.

title: New Trends in Neutrosophic Theories and Applications, Volume IV
affiliations: University of New Mexico and Nandalal Ghosh B.T. College

detail.title: New Trends in Neutrosophic Theories and Applications, Volume IV
detail.abstract:
The domain of neutrosophic set theory has been undergoing significant and rapid expansion. New approaches, theories, strategies, and optimization techniques are developed at a swift rate. An important development in neutrosophic theory is its integration with existing set theories, such as soft set theory, rough set theory and more. Neutrosophic set has been extended to neutrosophic hyperset which is vast and extends across multiple disciplines and problem domains, from decision support and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to data analysis and complex systems modelling. A neutrosophic hypersoft set extends the flexibility of neutrosophic logic and soft set theory by considering multidimensional or hypersoft sets to address real-world complexities where information is incomplete, uncertain, or inconsistent. Neutrosophic theories have emerged as essential tools in a diverse range of disciplines, including, MCDM, data mining, biomedical research, social studies, and beyond.

The fourth volume of “New Trends in Neutrosophic Theories and Applications” focuses on theories, strategies, optimizing techniques for MCDM within neutrosophic frameworks. Some topics deal with introducing of Pythagorean hypersoft sets with possibility degree, quadripartitioned neutrosophic Lie-ideal of Lie-algebra, quadripartitioned neutrosophic quasi coincident topological space, neutrosophic supra-open set in neutrosophic supra topological space and neutrosophic soft matrices. Some topics deal with medical diagnosis, organ transplantation success using neutrosophic superhyperstructure and artificial intelligence. Some topics deal with revenue management, social situation. Some topics deal with MCDM in single valued neutrosophic set environment, rough set environment, and interval trapezoidal neutrosophic environment.

title: Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control for Optimal Scheduling of Green Hydrogen Production and Revenue Maximisation
affiliations: Independent researcher, Ørsted AS, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Ørsted AS

detail.title: Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control for Optimal Scheduling of Green Hydrogen Production and Revenue Maximisation
detail.abstract: Hydrogen Purchase Agreements (HPAs) guarantee revenue streams that mitigate the financial risks inherent in the long-term production of green hydrogen from renewable energy sources. However, the intermittency of renewable electricity and the availability of parallel revenue opportunities in both the electricity and hydrogen markets complicate the scheduling of green hydrogen production. The scheduling should maximise the total revenue from short-term sales of electricity and hydrogen against the long-term HPA delivery obligations. This challenge is addressed by developing a Bounded Fuzzy Logic Control (BFLC) which determines the daily HPA delivery target based on day-ahead forecasts of electricity and hydrogen prices, as well as wind capacity factors. Subsequently, the daily target is imposed as a constraint in dispatch optimisation which allocates energy and hydrogen flows for each hour of the day.Revenue comparisons over several years demonstrate that the BFLC achieves total annual revenues within 9\% of optimal revenues that are based on perfect foresight. The BFLC revenues consistently exceed those of steady control, with the largest differences observed under conditions of elevated price levels and variability. The BFLC provides an effective long-term scheduling of green hydrogen production, enabling realistic revenue quantification that mitigates economic risks without overlooking economically viable projects.

title: Environmental, Economic, and Social Implications of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Last-Mile Delivery
affiliations: Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University, Zhejiang University and Zhejiang University

detail.title: Environmental, Economic, and Social Implications of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles for Last-Mile Delivery
detail.abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are technically appealing for last-mile parcel delivery, but its sustainability remains underexamined. Here we assess the life cycle environmental, economic and social impacts of three last-mile parcel delivery modes, namely BAU (parcels are delivered by an electric vehicle and a courier), UAV (parcels are delivered by UAVs), and CO (parcels are delivered by UAVs and electric vehicle), based on Monte Carlo simulations using real-world settings from a representative community. The results indicate that CO is the poorest-performing mode from the environmental perspective but is the best from the economic and social aspects. Our factorial analysis demonstrates that polymer lithium batteries reduce carbon emissions by 24.71% compared to lithium-ion batteries but cost 7.6 times more. We also observe that UAV generates lower carbon emissions in detached houses or for small parcels (0.10-1.99 kg and 0.0002-0.0199 m3) deliveries. Furthermore, we offer implications to guide research and practices.

title: Mind the Gap! Cognitive and Structural Microfoundations in Brokerage Through International Networks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Adelaide

detail.title: Mind the Gap! Cognitive and Structural Microfoundations in Brokerage Through International Networks
detail.abstract: This study theorizes why and when brokers choose to connect foreign outsiders with local insiders, extending social exchange and power-dependence theories. In today’s complex global business environment, brokers play a key role in helping foreign entrepreneurs overcome the gap - liability of outsidership to access local networks. Yet, the cognitive and structural mechanisms behind brokers’ decisions remain underexplored. Drawing on a multiple-case study of Chinese entrepreneurs in France, we theorize a cognitive-structural framework centered on two dimensions: the relative attractiveness of outsiders (i.e., their perceived value in terms of resources, knowledge, and offerings), and the tolerance for outsider replaceability (i.e., brokers’ willingness to risk being bypassed after making an introduction). Our informants have played roles both as brokers and as outsiders, allowing us to capture how role-switching experiences shape their understanding of brokerage dynamics. While brokers are more likely to facilitate ties with highly attractive outsiders, their tolerance depends on the expected returns: it is ‘low’ when insiders offer more, ‘moderate’ when returns are in balance, and ‘high’ when outsiders are more valuable. This study thus advances international business research by revealing the microfoundations of brokerage as a strategic, power-sensitive process.

title: The Impact of Hospital Mergers & Acquisitions on the Access to Care and Health Outcomes for Medicaid Beneficiaries
affiliations: Brown University - Department of Health Services, Policy & Practice

detail.title: The Impact of Hospital Mergers & Acquisitions on the Access to Care and Health Outcomes for Medicaid Beneficiaries
detail.abstract: I investigate the short-term effects of hospital mergers & acquisitions (M&As) on (1) care access, (2) care processes, and (3) health outcomes for Medicaid beneficiaries. With ongoing hospital consolidation widening the gap between private health insurance (PHI) and Medicaid inpatient reimbursements in the US, a critical question arises: Do hospitals potentially neglect Medicaid beneficiaries in favor of the more lucrative PHI patients, or do larger hospital systems increase the efficiency and effectiveness of care for this population? Using a staggered difference-in-differences approach, I find that while hospital M&As result in an over 15.5% merger-induced increase in system market shares, they do not significantly impact care access, care processes, or health outcomes for Medicaid beneficiaries in the short term.

title: Streamflow Forecasting Based on Patch Time Series Transformer and Ensemble Learning Approaches
affiliations: University of Tabriz and University of Tabriz

detail.title: Streamflow Forecasting Based on Patch Time Series Transformer and Ensemble Learning Approaches
detail.abstract: Accurate streamflow forecasting plays a crucial role in efficient water resource management, flood mitigation, and hydrological planning. Traditional methods often face limitations in identifying and modeling the complex temporal dependencies inherent in streamflow data. Therefore, this study investigates the performance of two deep learning models— Patch Time Series Transformer (PatchTST) and Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) —for daily streamflow forecasting of the Sefidrud River. The LSTM model is capable of capturing sequential and long-term dependencies in time series, whereas PatchTST leverages the Transformer architecture to extract both local and global features simultaneously. To enhance forecasting accuracy, an ensemble learning approach, including Stacking and Weighted Averaging methods is proposed, aiming to exploit the complementary strengths of the two models. The number of input lags was determined using a VAR approach, with two streamflow lag terms selected as model inputs. Model performance was evaluated using both numerical metrics and graphical analyses. The results indicate that the proposed Stacking Ensemble method outperforms individual models, achieving an RMSE=1.593 m³/s, MAE=1.333 m³/s, NS=0.991, and CC= 0.998. These findings highlight the potential of the Stacking Ensemble as a robust and novel approach for hydrological forecasting, particularly for daily streamflow prediction in mountainous and semi-humid regions.

title: A Brief Introduction to the Study of the Conceptual Development of Ethics in Early 20th-Century Egyptian Journalism
affiliations: The Autonomous University of Barcelona

detail.title: A Brief Introduction to the Study of the Conceptual Development of Ethics in Early 20th-Century Egyptian Journalism
detail.abstract: This note examines how early 20th-century Egyptian journalism reflected and reshaped ethical concepts like Amanah (honesty), highlighting changes in moral judgment amid political and cultural shifts.

title: Public Communication and Collusion: New Screening Tools for Competition Authorities
affiliations: German Institute for Economic Research (DIW Berlin), University of Pennsylvania, German Institute for Economic Research (DIW Berlin), Students and Heinrich Heine University Dusseldorf - Duesseldorf Institute for Competition Economics (DICE)

detail.title: Public Communication and Collusion: New Screening Tools for Competition Authorities

publicationDetails.journalName: CESifo Working Paper Series

detail.abstract: Competition authorities increasingly rely on economic screening tools to identify markets where firms deviate from competitive norms. Traditional screening methods assume that collusion occurs through secret agreements. However, recent research highlights that firms can use public announcements to coordinate decisions, reducing competition while avoiding detection. We propose a novel approach to screening for collusion in public corporate statements. Using natural language processing, we analyze more than 300, 000 earnings call transcripts issued worldwide between 2004 and 2022. By identifying expressions commonly associated with collusion, our method provides competition authorities with a tool to detect potentially anticompetitive behavior in public communications. Our approach can extend beyond earnings calls to other sources, such as news articles, trade press, and industry reports. Our method informed the European Commission’s 2024 unannounced inspections in the car tire sector, prompted by concerns over price coordination through public communication.

detail.abstract: The sequence of environmental disasters that has affected Italy in recent decades has influenced individuals' decisions about their location, especially in areas with high hydrogeological and seismic risk. This article aims to investigate the socioeconomic and behavioural factors that influence individuals' decisions to reside in areas of high environmental risk. Using Casamicciola Terme (Isola d'Ischia, Italy) as a case study, a multidisciplinary framework integrating environmental economics, risk perception theory and game-theoretic modelling is developed. In addition, an empirical survey was conducted to assess resident awareness, trust in institutions and preference for transfer or mitigation. The results reveal a persistent gap between perceived and actual risk, influenced by familiarity, socioeconomic resilience and institutional credibility. In addition, economic policy instruments such as insurance schemes, compensation and tax incentives can significantly influence willingness to move. The study helps to understand behavioural inertia in hazardous areas and proposes guidelines for targeted environmental policies in risk areas.

title: Aggregate Demand Flexibility Optimization Mechanisms: Evaluation and Application in Wholesalemarkets and Smart Distribution Networks
affiliations: Polytechnic University of Valencia, affiliation not provided to SSRN, Universidad Católica de Cuenca, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Universidad de Cuenca

detail.title: Aggregate Demand Flexibility Optimization Mechanisms: Evaluation and Application in Wholesalemarkets and Smart Distribution Networks
detail.abstract: The growing integration of intermittent renewable energy sources and the evolution of electricity marketshave intensified the need for effective mechanisms to optimize aggregate demand flexibility. This study examinesvarious optimization strategies applied to wholesale electricity markets and smart distribution networks, aimingto improve the integration of demand-side flexibility into system planning and operation. A thorough analysis ofaggregation mechanisms focuses on enhancing market stability and efficiency. detail.title: Comparing the Effect of Cross-Border and Domestic Mergers and Acquisitions on Acquirers' Price Reactions in the United States
detail.abstract: In the contemporary world, the Mergers and Acquisitions (M&A) market is remarkably dynamic, increasing in overall volume and value. Various factors influence the abnormal return of acquiring firms in M&A transactions, among which the cross-border status is particularly crucial. This study examines the effect of cross-border and domestic M&A transactions on acquirer price reactions, using a sample of 3893 M&A deals involving both public and private targets by United States listed firms, during the period 1999-2007. The results of the quantitative analysis indicate that cross-border M&A transactions generate lower stock returns for shareholders around the announcement date compared to domestic M&As. Additionally, acquirer size is negatively related to share returns, while the book-to-market ratio is positively associated with abnormal returns. Considering the public status of the target, this study finds that cross-border acquisitions of listed targets may lead to higher returns and mitigate the negative effects typically observed in cross-border M&As. With the findings, the study contributes to complementing existing literature and providing insights into M&A transactions by using comprehensive and typical M&A data. It suggests potential influencing factors for acquirers’ returns, emphasising cross-border complexity and targets’ public status. This study provides strategic insights for managers and valuable signals for individual investors, especially under today’s global market volatility. The findings bridge academic research with practical application, enriching the understanding of value creation in M&A activities, and offering a benchmark for future research on M&A.

detail.abstract: This study aims to examine the relationships of sustainability performance, partnerships to achieve the 17 SDGs. and leadership competencies on global university rankings. The study is based on the theory of Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR), the theory of Shareholder Value (SVT), and Transformational Leadership. This study used a cross-sectional explanatory research design involving 351 respondents from four state universities and colleges in Region VII, Philippines. The evaluation focused on 35 items, with 19 statements being eliminated after EFA and CFA. The SEM showed a satisfactory fit. The results challenge the established theories by revealing the lack of direct relationships between environmental sustainability and sustainability performance. Meanwhile, economic sustainability shows significant affect with CSR and SVT principles. The impact of social sustainability remains inconclusive, but partnerships affect sustainability performance. Leadership competencies affect the global rankings but not on sustainability performance. Acknowledging the limitations, this study recommends to expand the sample representation, incorporate empirical methods, explore the eliminated statements, conduct longitudinal and cross-cultural studies, encourage interdisciplinary collaboration, and evaluate policy impacts to develop more effective strategies for sustainability in Philippine HEIs.

detail.title: Machine Learning-Driven Optimization of Air Bubble Curtain Locations for Controlling Sea Water Intrusion
detail.abstract: Sea Water Intrusion (SWI) poses a significant threat to freshwater resources in coastal regions, and one promising mitigation strategy is the use of Air Bubble Curtains (ABCs), particularly through optimizing their discharge volume. This study conducted a total of 81 laboratory tests, varying flow rates, and salinity levels to evaluate the performance of ABCs in three distinct positions. Utilizing machine learning techniques—specifically Random Forest (RF), Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost), and Support Vector Regression (SVR)—the research aims to identify the optimal locations for ABC installation (Lˊ) and their discharge (Qa). The findings indicate that the XGBoost model outperforms the others in predicting the discharge of ABCs, achieving R2 = 0.926, RMSE = 0.023, and MAE = 0.019. Utilizing XGBoost, sensitivity analysis revealed that the densimetric Froude number exerts the most significant influence on Qa. Optimization results utilizing XGBoost show that when the importance weights of objectives (ω Qa and ωLˊ) are equal, the optimal location ratio (Lˊ/Average freshwater depth) is approximately 0.52; however, as these weights change, the optimized location ratio varies accordingly. This flexible, weighted optimization approach allows decision-makers to tailor ABC positioning to their specific priorities, whether focusing on cost-effectiveness or water quality, ultimately enhancing the management of freshwater resources impacted by SWI.

detail.title: Integrating Ai and Simulation for End-to-End Mine-to-Mill Optimisation: A Meta-Modelling Framework
detail.abstract: The growing global demand for mineral resources is challenging mining operations to maintain productivity while addressing lower-grade ore and increased extraction complexity. Despite the availability of vast datasets across mining stages, much of this information remains underused in decision-making. This study presents an integrated, knowledge-based framework that leverages artificial intelligence (AI) and high-fidelity simulation to model and optimise the full mine-to-mill process. Using publicly available data from the Barrick Cortez Mine in Nevada, USA, the mining chain from blasting to semi-autogenous grinding (SAG) was modelled using Orica’s Integrated Extraction Simulator (IES). To mitigate the computational burden of full factorial simulations, three million scenarios were generated to evaluate performance sensitivity. Machine learning models, including linear regression, decision trees, random forests, and XGBoost, were trained and validated. The models achieved an accuracy of more than 90%, underscoring their reliability for predicting fragmentation outcomes. SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) were applied to interpret model predictions and quantify feature importance. The findings confirm a strong alignment between simulation and real-world data and highlight key operational parameters that affect downstream performance. This meta-model approach offers a powerful tool for real-time decision-making, enabling mining operations to improve efficiency, reduce costs, and support sustainable resource management.

detail.abstract: The present-day business supply chains require proficient inventory management techniques to achieve operational superiority and minimize costs. The research presents an advanced inventory management revolution through a new AI chatbot system based on Groq’s Large Language Model (LLM) system. The backend implements FastAPI to merge with CSV or NoSQL database structures while providing scalable performance. detail.abstract: This paper proposes an innovative framework to enhance the participation of building load aggregators in real-time demand response (DR) electricity markets through optimized bidding strategies. With the increasing integration of renewable energy sources introducing variability and uncertainty into power grids, buildings, as significant electricity consumers, offer substantial potential for DR by dynamically adjusting their consumption. We develop a comprehensive model for building loads, incorporating economic factors through detailed dispatch cost calculations and employing a Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR) based metric to manage uncertainties effectively. A novel training environment is constructed using Kernel Density Estimation (KDE) to fit marginal distributions of critical variables and Vine Copulas to capture their complex multivariate dependencies, providing a high-fidelity simulation of market dynamics. This environment trains a Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (TD3) reinforcement learning agent to optimize quantity-price bidding decisions in continuous action spaces. The TD3 algorithm, with its twin critics and delayed policy updates, mitigates overestimation bias and ensures policy stability, outperforming traditional methods like the Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG). Validation using ISO New England market data demonstrates that our approach significantly improves profitability and risk management for load aggregators, with the KDE-vine copula model offering superior accuracy over neural network-based alternatives and the TD3 agent achieving stable, high-reward outcomes.

detail.title: Healthcare Procurement and Firm Innovation: Evidence from Ai-Powered Equipment
detail.abstract: This paper explores whether technological learning between hospitals and supplier firms is associated with suppliers’ innovative performance. Our empirical analysis relies on a dataset combining unprecedented granular data on procurement bids and equipment with patent data measuring suppliers’ innovative performance. We identify the firm’s innovative activity relevant to the bid by using an advanced neural network algorithm for text analysis. This procedure allows us to match in an original way firm’s equipment descriptions with relevant patent documents. We then employ a difference-in-differences approach alongside a regression discontinuity design to estimate the causal effect of becoming a supplier on firms’ patents in the relevant IPC classes. Our results show that firms becoming hospital suppliers have a significantly higher propensity to innovate. About the mechanism, we show that supplying AI-powered equipment further boosts the suppliers’ innovative performance. Our results raise important policy implications in terms of the conduct and design of procurement bids in healthcare and in the precision medicine domain.
