detail.abstract: Theory suggests that in the face of fire-sale externalities, banks have incentives to overinvest in order to issue excessive money-like deposit liabilities. The existence of a private market for insurance such as contingent capital can eliminate the overinvestment incentives, leading to efficient outcomes. However, it does not eliminate fire sales. A central bank that can infuse liquidity cheaply may be motivated to intervene in the face of fire sales. If so, it can crowd out the private market and, if liquidity intervention is not priced at higher-than-breakeven rates, induce overinvestment. We examine various forms of public intervention to identify the least distortionary ones. Our analysis helps understand the historical prevalence of private insurance in the era preceding central banks and deposit insurance, their subsequent disappearance, as well as the continuing incidence of banking crises and speculative excesses. * We are grateful to Agustin Carstens, Anastasios Dosis, Kristin Forbes (discussant), Pierre-Olivier Gourinchas (discussant)

title: [Discussion Paper]Considerations on Cross-Shareholding in the Modern Era: Focusing on the Correction of  Shareholder Capitalism
affiliations: The Chinese University of Hong Kong and Keio University - Graduate School of System Design and Management

detail.title: [Discussion Paper]Considerations on Cross-Shareholding in the Modern Era: Focusing on the Correction of  Shareholder Capitalism

declarations.funderStatement: Grant-in-Aid was provided by Keio University Academic Development Fund (H08JAK2439) in the year 2024.

detail.abstract:
The form of corporate governance can vary depending on the ideals, ideas, and values that underlie the vision for the kind of society we aim to build. Japan has designed its Corporate Governance Code based on the premise that the Anglo-American governance system, which prioritizes capital markets and shareholder interests above all else, is the global standard. However, if we aim for a corporate governance system that emphasizes the social responsibility of companies, cross-shareholding is not necessarily a flaw in corporate governance. Rather, it can function as a mechanism to protect Japan's national interests.

This paper first traces the evolution of cross-shareholding since the 1950s and confirms through literature review that the existence of stable shareholders through cross-shareholding contributed to long-term management, provided a stable environment for research and development for manufacturing companies, mitigated pressure from short-term shareholders, and contributed to management that took into account stakeholders other than shareholders, such as employees. Next, we showed that although “multi-stakeholder focus” is now a fundamental principle, individual institutional designs incorporate systems that are compatible with maximizing shareholder value in financial capital markets, and that reforms based on soft law that prioritize capital markets have taken precedence over revisions to hard law such as the Companies Act, resulting in a system design and management that favors investors.

Even today, the role of cross-shareholding in embodying the strengths of Japanese-style management remains unchanged. Rather, in the current stage where global capital flows and shareholder activism are becoming increasingly active, the paper highlights the need to recognize the necessity of a “modern version of cross-shareholding” and suggests the need to reconsider the flexible utilization of cross-shareholding while appropriately and timely implementing reforms in both soft law and hard law.

title: Global-Local Skeleton Constraint-Based Bim-Gis Integration Modeling Method for Railway Infrastructure
affiliations: Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University, Southwest Jiaotong University and Chengdu Normal University

detail.title: Global-Local Skeleton Constraint-Based Bim-Gis Integration Modeling Method for Railway Infrastructure
detail.abstract: As digital twin technology is increasingly integrated into intelligent operation and maintenance (O&M) for railways, achieving the efficient integration, automated deployment, and dynamic updating of BIM and GIS models has become a key challenge in railway infrastructure automation construction. Existing BIM-GIS integration methods face challenges such as low automation, inadequate spatial matching accuracy, and poor model loading efficiency. This study proposes a BIM-GIS integration modeling method based on global-local skeleton constraints. This method defines and extracts a global-local skeleton model as a geometric spatial constraint, automating BIM component layout and assembly. Simultaneously, an intelligent deployment mechanism is established to enable the automated invocation and efficient deployment of components. Verification with real-world railway infrastructure confirms that the method enhances the automation, spatial accuracy, and efficiency of BIM-GIS integration, providing strong technical support for infrastructure construction automation.

title: Floodtransformer: Efficient Real-Time High-Resolution Flood Forecasting
affiliations: University of Technology Sydney (UTS), affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, University of Adelaide, affiliation not provided to SSRN and University of Technology Sydney (UTS)

detail.title: Floodtransformer: Efficient Real-Time High-Resolution Flood Forecasting
detail.abstract: Flood forecasting is a critical component of disaster planning and risk management, requiring systems that are both scientifically rigorous and operationally efficient. Conventional hydrodynamic-based approaches are limited by their slow response time and are often computationally costly to achieve large-scale, high-resolution predictions. In this study, we present a hybrid framework that incorporates the traditional hydrodynamic models with an innovative, efficient FloodTransformer framework, enabling accurate, real-time, and high-resolution flood forecasting. We first schematise a 3Di hydrodynamic model based on the region’s geographical characteristics, rigorously validating and calibrating it against real-world observations. Using this model, hundreds of simulations representing a wide range of rainfall patterns, initial water depths, and boundary conditions are then generated and used to train the AI model. To address the computational limitations preventing the adoption of advanced AI techniques for large-scale, fine-grained rasterised spatiotemporal analysis, our FloodTransformer introduces: (1) novel size embeddings to directly encode variable-sized grid cells, and (2) tokenised time-sequence encodings that capture multi-modal temporal dependencies without significant computational overhead. This temporal tokenisation mechanism also ensures efficient sequential predictions in a single run, minimising error accumulation in iterative prediction approaches. Furthermore, our physics-informed multi-task optimisation further enhances water depth prediction accuracy through integrated regularisation. Extensive experiments on both simulated datasets and real-world historical flood events are conducted using widely adopted hydrographic evaluation metrics. The results demonstrate FloodTransformer as an innovative solution for managing flash flooding risks with both high accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Cognitive Castes: Artificial Intelligence, Epistemic Stratification, and the Dissolution of Democratic Discourse
affiliations: University of Exeter

detail.title: Cognitive Castes: Artificial Intelligence, Epistemic Stratification, and the Dissolution of Democratic Discourse
detail.abstract: Artificial intelligence functions not as an epistemic leveller, but as an accelerant of cognitive stratification, entrenching and formalising informational castes within liberal-democratic societies. Synthesising formal epistemology, political theory, algorithmic architecture, and economic incentive structures, the argument traces how contemporary AI systems selectively amplify the reasoning capacity of individuals equipped with recursive abstraction, symbolic logic, and adversarial interrogation-whilst simultaneously pacifying the cognitively untrained through engagement-optimised interfaces. Fluency replaces rigour, immediacy displaces reflection, and procedural reasoning is eclipsed by reactive suggestion. The result is a technocratic realignment of power: no longer grounded in material capital alone, but in the capacity to navigate, deconstruct, and manipulate systems of epistemic production. Information ceases to be a commons; it becomes the substrate through which consent is manufactured and autonomy subdued. Deliberative democracy collapses not through censorship, but through the erosion of interpretive agency. The proposed response is not technocratic regulation, nor universal access, but the reconstruction of rational autonomy as a civic mandate-codified in education, protected by epistemic rights, and structurally embedded within open cognitive infrastructure.

title: Fuzzy-Based Risk Assessment for Uav Deforestation Monitoring Under Adverse Weather
affiliations: University of Tsukuba and University of Tsukuba

detail.title: Fuzzy-Based Risk Assessment for Uav Deforestation Monitoring Under Adverse Weather
detail.abstract: Deforestation monitoring is a crucial activity to protect natural forests, conserve ecological biodiversity, and mitigate Earth’s climate change. Recently, uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) have greatly enhanced deforestation monitoring by enabling high-resolution and real-time detection of illegal activities and forest fires. However, effective UAV operations are significantly hindered by adverse weather conditions such as heavy rainfall, strong winds, dense fog, and extreme heat. In order to assess external environmental risks of UAV-based monitoring and explore effective risk mitigations, this paper presents a novel risk analysis methodology. We propose Risk-Driven Failure Mode Effect Analysis (RD-FMEA) that extends the conventional FMEA by incorporating risk factors affecting the failure modes of system components. RD-FMEA introduces fuzzy logic to assign the risk scores to individual failure modes associated with the identified risk factors. We apply RD-FMEA to a UAV-based deforestation monitoring system considering the risk of adverse weather conditions. The risk analysis results suggest that heavy rainfall poses the most significant risk that can involve many failure modes. We further investigate four different mitigation approaches against adverse weather conditions and evaluate their effectiveness. Through the comparative analysis of RD-FMEA results, we find that the introduction of an intelligent water drops algorithm can significantly reduce the risk scores, by helping UAVs’ route planning to avoid heavy rainfalls. Moreover, we show that the risk scores can be further reduced by adding rules to abort missions by predefined time threshold to avoid unsafe continuous UAV operations in adverse weather conditions.

title: Exploring Connections between Climate Action and Regional Development in the East African Community
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

detail.title: Exploring Connections between Climate Action and Regional Development in the East African Community
detail.abstract: There is a need to bridge policy and implementation gaps between national adaptation plans, nationally determined contributions, and sustainable development. In East Africa, rapid population growth and climate change impacts intensify demands for water, energy, and food (WEF), fuelling resource exploitation. Sustainable development plans aim to meet resource demands while building resilience, necessitating a multi-sectoral approach. This study employs a mixed-qualitative methodology to explore the interlinkages between nationally determined contributions, national adaptation plans and regional development in East Africa. Results show implied connections between policy instruments, sustainable development, and climate action form the crux of WEF interlinkages. WEF resource insecurity is worsened by incoherent national development plans, which create competition for shared resources and tradeoffs instead of fostering collaboration. For example, the focus on food security, mostly through extensification, has created tradeoffs with water and energy security, undermining development goals. Understanding the interconnectedness and interdependencies between sector policies, climate actions, and supranational development plans could catalyse and accelerate Sustainable Development Goals 1, 2, 6, 7, 8, 9 and 13 and goals related to the Paris Agreement. There are implicit interlinkages and, to a certain extent, in practice. Although insufficient, these are foundations for a bottom-up approach to implementing integrated climate action commitments. The WEF nexus approach provides an opportunity to break policy and action siloes in East Africa. Ultimately, a transdisciplinary approach focused on equity, social justice, sustainability, and a just transition is required to support development agendas.

title: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Social Justice
affiliations: Srinivas University

detail.title: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar and Social Justice
detail.abstract: Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the principal architect of the Indian Constitution, was a visionary reformer and relentless advocate for social justice. Born into a Dalit community, Ambedkar's personal experiences with caste discrimination shaped his lifelong mission to dismantle social hierarchies and promote equality. Through his academic excellence, legal expertise, and political activism, he championed the rights of the marginalized, particularly the Scheduled Castes and Tribes. His concept of social justice extended beyond legal equality to encompass economic empowerment, gender justice, and the annihilation of caste. As a constitutionalist, he ensured that democratic principles and human rights were embedded in the Indian legal framework. His conversion to Buddhism represented a spiritual and social revolution, providing dignity and identity to millions. This study examines Ambedkar's life, ideology, and lasting impact on India's pursuit of an inclusive and equitable society.

title: Sanctions Paradox: Do U.S. Export Restrictions Hurt Domestic Innovation?
affiliations: Tsinghua University - PBC School of Finance, Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Sloan School of Management and Sun Yat-sen University (SYSU)

detail.title: Sanctions Paradox: Do U.S. Export Restrictions Hurt Domestic Innovation?
detail.abstract: Yes. We find that U.S. export restrictions reduce innovation incentives among U.S. firms that export to sanctioned entities. These restrictions prompt targeted foreign firms to accelerate their own innovation efforts, ostensibly with increased support from their governments-including weakening enforcement of U.S. intellectual property rights (IPR). Weaker IPR diminishes the ability of U.S. suppliers to appropriate the returns from their R&D investments, leading them to reduce R&D spending by 13% and R&D-related hiring by 9%. Post-sanctions, suppliers to sanctioned firms also shift their IP protection strategy: patent filings decline by 10%, while mentions of trade secrets in regulatory filings rise by 47%. These effects are stronger when sanctioned entities are likely to reverse-engineer their suppliers' technology and weaker when domestic competition necessitates U.S. firms to innovate. The impact is most pronounced in patent-intensive industries and for suppliers who hold patents in sanctioned countries. Our findings suggest that export controls may unintentionally fuel foreign innovation and IP appropriation, prompting U.S. firms to scale back innovation and favor secrecy over patenting.

title: Competitive Concerns from Pharmacy Benefit Managers Selling Their Own Drugs
affiliations: Rutgers, The State University of New Jersey - Rutgers Law School and Washington University in Saint Louis - School of Law

detail.title: Competitive Concerns from Pharmacy Benefit Managers Selling Their Own Drugs
detail.abstract:
Brand-name drug prices in the United States are higher than they should be.  One reason is that the complex regulatory regime intended to increase competition and reduce prices after brand drugs' patent terms have expired has not been fully effective. Policymakers and scholars have focused on ensuring regulatory approval and market entry of lower-priced competitors to brand drugs, but few have analyzed a subsequent stage of competition: being accessible to consumers.  Just because a manufacturer is permitted to sell a lower-priced product does not mean that more affordable version will be made available to patients. 

Here, the frequently-discussed pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs) play a role. PBMs create and maintain formularies, lists of drugs covered by insurance plans. Because of the leading PBMs' market power, drugs not covered on formularies tend to be inaccessible to patients. Formularies were supposed to encourage the use of cost-effective drugs. But today, it seems that PBMs are using formularies to increase their own financial rewards. 

In this essay, we examine a new development in PBMs' conduct: the allowance of a limited amount of self-serving competition on formularies. The largest PBMs have recently gotten into the business of selling drugs in combination with drug manufacturers. These PBMs also have excluded from their formularies drugs competing with those in which the PBM and some manufacturers have a common financial interest, even if that would not be the most cost-effective option for patients. Although this self-serving competition could reduce prices in the short term, it threatens at least two downsides: (1) forestalling even greater price reductions and (2) harming long-term competition and innovation. 

This essay explains PBMs' role in creating formularies, increasing use of formulary exclusion, and newfound involvement with selling drugs. It then analyzes the competitive effects of this new behavior and analyzes potential antitrust claims including self-preferencing, exclusive dealing, collusion, and unfair competition.

detail.abstract: Ten Ghanaian public university libraries were investigated to determine if they conform to universal design principles to accommodate students with disabilities. The study employed a multiple case study design and was underpinned by the Social Model of Disability. A mixed methods approach was adopted employing online questionnaires, in-depth interviews to gather data from university librarians, heads of the physical development office, heads of disability units and students with visual, mobile, and hearing impairments. An observation checklist for access to the library facilities and resources was conducted, and the data were analysed thematically.  Findings revealed that most of the university libraries were not universally designed to accommodate the needs of students with disabilities which impacted negatively on information access, participation, and academic performance of these students. detail.title: Evaluating the Impacts of Building Retrofits on U.S. Low-Income Households: A Data-Driven Approach
detail.abstract: The building sector represents a significant portion of energy consumption in the U.S., accounting for 40% of total energy demand and 76% of electricity usage. Building energy retrofits are a critical strategy for reducing this energy footprint, offering substantial opportunities to improve energy efficiency, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and lower operational costs. This is particularly important for low-income households (LIHs), who often reside in older, energy-inefficient homes, resulting in a higher building operation cost and energy burden. Retrofitting measures can help reduce this burden, but their effectiveness must be carefully assessed due to financial constraints. Many programs aimed at enhancing energy consumption for low-income groups exist, but studies of their impact are limited to specific areas and case studies due to the lack of a comprehensive large-scale national building energy data. This research proposes integrating two national datasets, the Residential Energy Consumption Survey (RECS) and American Housing Survey (AHS), to address this information gap and comprehensively analyze the energy consumption patterns and retrofitting impacts on low-income housing nationwide. By integrating these data sources using a two-stage machine learning approach, the study aims to provide a more accurate assessment of energy efficiency improvement and identify the most effective retrofitting strategies for reducing energy burdens on LIHs.

English Abstract: With an investment of over 700 million euros, the public sector is the main advertiser in the Spanish market. Altogether, the central, regional, and local governments launch more than 5000 institutional advertising and communication contracts. In Spain, these tenders are governed by Law 9/2017 on Public Sector Contracts and Law 19/2013 on Transparency, Access to Public Information and Good Governance, in compliance with which governments have developed openly accessible websites that provide practical information on the contracts for interested individuals and companies. This paper compares all regional procurement platforms through the study of a hundred institutional communication public contracts launched in 2021, assessing the usefulness of the published content, detecting good practices, and identifying gaps and areas of improvement. detail.abstract: Generative artificial intelligence is changing the way lawyers work, and with those changes have come questions and concerns about how it should be regulated. Those questions and concerns, particularly on the individual level, are driven by fears about the implications of the use of generative AI. This Article identifies and explores the fears that drive these regulatory responses: fear of exposing judicial fallibility, anxiety over AI replacing human lawyers, and concerns about missing out on AI’s potential benefits. detail.abstract: US population growth has slowed sharply in the past 18 months, as the immigration surge of the early 2020s has ended and the population continues to age. Fewer jobs are needed to keep up with the growth of the labor force, and growth rates of output and consumption will fall even if per capita output and consumption hold steady. The total US population is growing at an annualized rate of 0.5 percent, down from 1 percent in late 2023. I estimate the breakeven rate of monthly payroll growth in the jobs report needed to keep up with the labor force has fallen from 166,000 jobs in early 2024 to 86,000 jobs in June 2025. Accordingly, policymakers need to lower their targets and forecasts for key economic data and put more weight on per capita and other population-invariant measures. Adjusting expectations in light of slower population growth is essential for setting monetary policy, determining whether the United States is in recession, and other data-driven decisions and interpretations. With slower population growth, any given level of monthly payroll growth, consumption growth, or output growth reflects a stronger economy than it did a year ago. Population growth is not only slowing; it has also become more volatile and harder to estimate. It is likely that current population estimates for 2025 that statistical agencies are incorporating into economic data are too high and will be revised downward; current population estimates imply much higher immigration in 2025 than is likely under current administration policy. Economic data will need to be reinterpreted and revised in line with future adjustments to population estimates.

detail.abstract: While internationalization efforts can help startups overcome barriers to growth, entering foreign markets remains a significant challenge. Accelerator programs play an important role in supporting startups' scaling ambitions by offering in-depth entrepreneurial learning opportunities. In this study, we examine whether and how such programs can facilitate startup internationalization. To this end, we leverage a unique dataset that combines proprietary application data from the German Accelerator (GA)-a government-financed program designed to support startups' international market entry-with detailed startup-level, founder, and investment information. We find that participating startups significantly raised funding and hired more employees in the GA's target countries relative to a comparison group of startups that were admitted, but did not attend for exogenous reasons. Consistent with our theoretical considerations about an experiential learning mechanism, these effects are muted for startups that took part in online programs that were introduced in response to the COVID-19 pandemic, and the results are strongest among startups with limited international experience prior to participating. We further support these mechanisms with qualitative evidence from surveying GA alumni. Our study advances the understanding of the potential and limitations of startup accelerators in supporting international market entry, a key strategy for many entrepreneurial ventures today.

detail.title: Climate Policy Uncertainty and Firm Productivity: Evidence from a Multi-Country Decomposition Approach
detail.abstract: This study examines how climate policy uncertainty affects firm-level productivity and its core components, including technological change, scale efficiency, and allocative efficiency. Drawing on a translog production function and the decomposition method developed by Kumbhakar et al. in 1999, we analyze a panel dataset of 2,412 publicly listed firms in G7 countries from 1989 to 2023. The findings suggest that climate policy uncertainty does not influence total factor productivity immediately. Instead, its impact emerges over time as firms gradually respond to regulatory shifts. Technological change reacts quickly and positively, indicating that uncertainty can stimulate innovation. Allocative efficiency improves at a slower pace, reflecting the time needed for firms to adjust their resource allocations once policy direction becomes clearer. The effects on scale efficiency vary across firms and are shaped by characteristics such as size and liquidity. Companies with larger cash reserves often delay strategic input adjustments, suggesting that financial flexibility can reduce responsiveness. These outcomes highlight the dynamic and multifaceted nature of corporate adaptation to policy uncertainty. To support long-term productivity gains, climate policies should emphasize clarity, stability, and institutional credibility. Encouraging innovation is important, but helping firms reallocate resources effectively under uncertain conditions is equally essential. A predictable and gradual policy trajectory can reduce unnecessary caution, promote timely adjustments, and facilitate a more efficient transition toward sustainable practices.

detail.title: The Effects of Female Education on Energy Poverty and Fuel Choice
detail.abstract: Energy poverty affects over two billion people globally, yet causal evidence on its determinants remains limited. This study examines the causal relationship between female education and multidimensional energy poverty using quasi-experimental variation from Bangladesh's Female Secondary School Stipend Program (FSSSP), implemented from 1994 to 2008. Exploiting geographic and temporal variation in program exposure, we employ a two-stage least squares approach with data from three waves (2010, 2016, 2022) of the nationally representative Household Income and Expenditure Survey covering 48,123 households. Each additional year of female education reduces energy poverty by 0.12 points on our multidimensional index, representing a 39% improvement relative to the control group mean. Female education systematically shifts household energy consumption from traditional biomass fuels toward cleaner alternatives, with particularly large effects on severe energy poverty. The impacts operate through multiple mechanisms including economic empowerment (10% increase in wealth), demographic transitions (smaller household size, fewer children), assortative mating (19.5% increase in spouse education), and enhanced infrastructure decision-making agency. Threshold analysis reveals transformative effects at eighth-grade completion, while heterogeneity analysis shows benefits are concentrated among the poorest households. These findings provide the rigorous causal evidence that investments in female education generate substantial co-benefits for energy poverty reduction beyond their direct educational impacts, supporting integrated development approaches that recognize complementarities between human capital investments and energy access objectives.

detail.title: Domestic Uncertainty, Chinese Energy Engagements, and U.S. Administration Shifts Across Europe's Energy Policy Landscape
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of energy policy risk on low-carbon energy risk using annual data from 2000 to 2022 across 36 European countries. The study also considers the role of Chinese energy investment and U.S. presidential policy shifts. Through Method of Moments Quantile Regression (MMQR), Partially Linear Functional-Coefficient (PLFC) panel modelling, and Difference-in-Differences (DID) estimations, the results consistently show that energy policy risk exacerbates low-carbon energy risk, particularly in higher-risk countries and within specific climate risk intervals. DID findings further suggest that Chinese fossil energy investments significantly increase low-carbon energy risk, while renewable-only investments show no effect. Analysis of U.S. administrations reveals varied influences: Bush-era policies appear to reduce risk, whereas Trump and Biden interventions heighten it through different channels. These findings reinforce the importance of stable, transparent energy governance in Europe. Policymakers should prioritise institutional resilience and climate-aligned policy design to manage foreign investment impacts and buffer against global political shifts, fostering a secure and sustainable energy transition.

detail.title: Tests for No-Arbitrage in Cryptocurrency Markets
detail.abstract: This article investigates the efficiency of the cryptocurrency markets by testing the no-arbitrage hypothesis in a general framework for cryptocurrencies traded on multiple exchange platforms. We test the moment conditions implied by the no-arbitrage hypothesis by applying a simulated method of moments and a general specification test. For each of the five cryptocurrencies considered, the test is applied globally using the full sample and locally using a rolling window approach. Globally, the results show that the null hypothesis of no-arbitrage is rejected for Bitcoin and Ethereum, but is not rejected for Binance Coin and for the two stablecoins, USD Coin and Tether. Locally, the hypothesis is never rejected for USD Coin and is rejected 5.5% of the time for Tether. In comparison, the test rejects the hypothesis frequently for the three studied native cryptocurrencies (39.5% of the time for Bitcoin, 26% for Ethereum, and 21.5% for Binance Coin).

detail.abstract: This paper takes the mine roads in the waste dump of an open-pit coal mine as the research object. Industrial-grade sensors are used to ensure real-time and high-precision monitoring of dust concentration and environmental parameters. detail.title: Nonlinear Real Exchange Rate Adjustments: Insights from Ipad Price Data
detail.abstract: We investigate nonlinear real exchange rate (RER) dynamics using a high-frequency panel dataset of Apple iPad prices across global markets. Our findings challenge the conventional view of slow RER adjustment by demonstrating that larger mispricings are corrected much faster, while smaller deviations persist for longer periods. We identify a valuation threshold effect, where smaller deviations behave like unit root processes, while larger discrepancies are more quickly mean-reverting. Furthermore, the magnitude of these thresholds decrease as the evaluation time horizon increases. Transaction costs play a crucial role in shaping these dynamics, with higher costs associated with wider thresholds for arbitrage activity. Additionally, the results reveal asymmetry in RER adjustments, where undervaluations are corrected more rapidly than overvaluations. These findings provide new insights into the speed and nature of RER adjustments, suggesting that product-specific price data, such as that from iPads, can offer a more granular understanding of international price convergence.

detail.abstract: Elucidating spatiotemporal evolution patterns and driving mechanisms of Ecosystem Services (ES) facilitates the optimization of ES supply-demand structures and advances ecological management zoning objectives. Using China's Chengdu-Chongqing Economic Circle (CCEC) as a case study, this research employs a Water-Carbon-Soil (WCS) nexus framework to: (1) quantify spatiotemporal mismatches and trade-offs/synergies between ES supply and urbanization-driven demand, (2) reveal driving mechanisms underlying natural constraints and anthropogenic pressures, and (3) establish a three-tier adaptive zoning system where each zone implements hierarchical governance strategies to address region-specific supply-demand imbalances. Key findings reveal:(1) During 2000-2020, all three ES exhibited significant supply-demand clustering: Low supply-low demand clusters dominated water yield (WY, 20%) and soil retention (SR, 22%), while carbon sequestration (CS) was characterized predominantly by high supply-low demand clusters (26%).(2) The overall ES supply-demand balance deteriorated, with the Composite Ecosystem Supply-Demand Ratio (CESDR) declining from 0.149 to 0.111. This shift manifested spatially as "dual-core deficit expansion with peripheral surplus contraction".(3) Primary drivers of CESDR variation were population density (POP, mean β = -0.236), gross domestic product (GDP, mean β = -0.641), and normalized difference vegetation index (NDVI, mean β = 0.322), indicating negative anthropogenic pressures versus positive vegetation-mediated effects.(4) By integrating ES clustering patterns, CESDR dynamics, and key drivers, we delineated Core Restoration Zones, Flexible Regulation Zones, and Ecological Priority Conservation Zones at county and grid scales. This framework establishes a replicable paradigm for balancing ecological security and socioeconomic development in mega-urban agglomerations.

detail.abstract: This paper introduces a robust Bayesian optimization framework for high-precisiontime-delay estimation in GNSS receivers subject to multipath propagationand hardware impairments. Unlike conventional estimators that dependon idealized array models or extensive calibration, our approach exploitsa tensor-based representation of the received signal to leverage its multidi-mensional structure. A key innovation is the use of a mode-2 tensor factor-ization to decouple time-delay estimation from spatial distortions, yieldinga surrogate cost function that directly measures the time-delay alignmenterror. We then apply Bayesian optimization, guided by a Gaussian processsurrogate and an expected improvement acquisition function, to efficientlynavigate the time-delay parameter space. To guard against outliers andfurther improve accuracy, we integrate a nonlinear least-squares refinementstep using the Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno with bounds (L-BFGS-B)algorithm as a second stage. Simulation results demonstrate that the pro-posed method significantly outperforms state-of-the-art techniques such asleast square katri-rao factorization (LSKRF), achieving sub-meter accuracyeven in the presence of array calibration errors and multipath.

תקציר בעברית: מערכת המיסוי הבינלאומית הנוכחית, שעוצבה לפני למעלה ממאה שנה, מתקשה להתמודד עם אתגרי הכלכלה המודרנית. בעוד שבעבר ניתן היה להגדיר בקלות יחסית היכן נוצרה הכנסה והיכן בוצעה פעילות עסקית, הכלכלה הדיגיטלית והגלובלית של ימינו מציבה אתגרים חדשים הנובעים מכך שפעילות עסקית מתרחשת ברובה במרחב וירטואלי, ללא צורך בנוכחות פיזית, באופן שונה מהותית מהעולם שבעבורו עוצבו במקור כללי המיסוי הבינלאומי. נייר זה נועד לתרום להבנת המגמות הנוכחיות במיסוי בינלאומי והשפעתן על מדינת ישראל, על ידי פריסת סוגיות מרכזיות בעיצוב מערכת המס הבינלאומי העכשווית ומגמת התפתחותה. במיוחד, הנייר מציג ומנתח את הרפורמה המתגבשת במיסוי בינלאומי שבהובלת הארגון לשיתוף פעולה ולפיתוח כלכלי (ה-OECD), המכונה "רפורמת שני הנדבכים", בהנחה שהיא תתקדם ו/או תתבסס על מתכונתה הנוכחית. זאת, על רקע נקודת ההשקה שבין הרפורמה למערכת תמריצי המס ומדיניות ההשקעות במדינה.

ההצהרה על ההסכמה לגבי רפורמת שני הנדבכים נחתמה בשנת 2021 על ידי 136 מדינות חברות במסגרת המכילה של ה-OECD. שני נדבכי הרפורמה עוסקים בצדדים שונים אך משלימים הנוגעים להתפתחות מערכת המס הבינלאומית במרוצת השנים, ונועדו לתקן פרצות שנפערו בה בעידן הדיגיטלי של הכלכלה הגלובלית. על רקע זה, הנדבך הראשון מתרכז במיסוי חברות רב-לאומיות גדולות ורווחיות במיוחד. הוא יוצר זכות מיסוי חדשה, המעבירה חלק מהרווחים העסקיים המופקים על ידי אותן חברות גדולות ורווחיות במיוחד למדינות יעד או שוק להן ניתנו סחורות ו/או שירותים או בהן נמצא הצרכן הסופי. באופן זה מרחיב הנדבך הראשון את נתח המס של מדינות היעד או שוק (market destinations), ומאפשר להן לגבות מסים על יותר הכנסות. השפעתו של הנדבך הראשון על הכלכלה הגלובלית צפויה, ברוב המדינות, להיות קטנה, ובהתאם גם על הכלכלה הישראלית. לעומת זאת, הנדבך השני קובע מנגנון גלובלי למיסוי מינימלי אפקטיבי של חברות רב-לאומיות בשיעור של 15%. בכך מתמקד הנדבך השני בתופעת הסטת הרווחים ושחיקת בסיס המס שהתגברה מאוד בעשורים האחרונים, על ידי הצבת גבול לתחרות המס הבינלאומית. היקפו של הנדבך השני רחב מזה של הנדבך הראשון, הוא חל על חלק גדול יותר מהחברות, ועשוי להשפיע באופן משמעותי יותר על הכלכלה העולמית בכלל ועל כלכלת ישראל בפרט.

הניתוח בנייר מתייחס במיוחד להשפעות רפורמת שני הנדבכים על מערכת תמריצי המס ועל המדיניות הנדרשת על מנת לשמר את האטרקטיביות של מדינת ישראל להשקעות זרות במציאות המיסויית-כלכלית החדשה. בהקשר זה, פורס הנייר שלושה תרחישים מרכזיים להשלכות מדיניות של הרפורמה על ישראל, מהם עולה כי הרפורמה מציבה אתגרים כמו גם הזדמנויות לישראל, במיוחד בתחום תמריצי המס וההשקעות. האתגרים הם השינויים הנדרשים במערכת המס, כתוצאה מהרפורמה המתגבשת, והשפעותיהם על תמריצי חברות להשקיע בישראל. ההזדמנויות הן האפשרות להגדלת היקף גביית המסים בארץ אל מול פוטנציאל צימצום השימוש בהטבות מס על רקע מגמת הירידה בתחרות המס הבינלאומית והגברת שיתוף הפעולה המדיני-כלכלי.

המלצות הנייר כוללות בחינה של מערכת תמריצי המס לחברות על מנת לזהות אלו מהתמריצים רצוי לשמר, אלו לבטל, ואלו כדאי להמיר במענקים או בהטבות שלא באמצעות מס החברות, על מנת לשמר את יתרונה היחסי של מדינת ישראל במשיכת השקעות/פירמות בינלאומיות. לנוכח הירידה בפוטנציאל משיכת ההשקעות באמצעות הטבות מס, אנו ממליצים לבחון תמריצים חלופיים שעומדים בכללי הרפורמה, כגון זיכויי מס ההופכים למענקים ופישוט רגולטורי, ולמקד אותן בחברות שמניבות תועלת מיוחדת למשק: השקעות היוצרות ערך רחב יותר ממה שבא לידי ביטוי ברווחי החברה (״השפעות חיצוניות ליוביות״), או שהן בעלות ערך גבוה למשק ושיש לחברות המשקיעות יכולת לעזוב את ישראל. חשוב מכך, ויותר מתמיד, לאור הרפורמה יש לשפר גורמי יסוד כגון חינוך ותשתיות אחרות, על מנת לחזק את מעמדה של ישראל כמרכז עסקי בינלאומי. צעדים אלו יתמכו בצמיחתה הכלכלית של ישראל ובחסינותה הפיסקלית.

title: Welfare Convergence in the Brazilian States
affiliations: FEA-RP/USP, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Sao Paulo School of Economics (EESP-FGV)

detail.title: Welfare Convergence in the Brazilian States
detail.abstract: The paper of Jones and Klenow (2016) introduces an alternative measure for economic wellbeing, incorporating consumption, leisure, and life expectancy data to mitigate the limitations of the GDP metric. Based on their approach, we examine the well-being dynamics among Brazilian states from 2002 to 2017. Our findings reveal a substantial improvement in well-being across nearly all states, with life expectancy emerging as the primary driver of this enhancement. Over the period, we observed a substantial 47% average increase in well-being, surpassing income growth by a substantial margin of 25 percentage points. Moreover, GDP per capita and well-being exhibited convergence. Considering the half-life approach, our estimations indicate that states would reach half of the convergence towards the steady-state in well-being within 29 years, in contrast to 55 years for GDP per capita.

title: Integrating Stochastic Optimization and Monte Carlo Simulation for an Extended Hub-and-Spoke Archipelagic Shipping Network Under Uncertainties on Feeder Nodes
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Integrating Stochastic Optimization and Monte Carlo Simulation for an Extended Hub-and-Spoke Archipelagic Shipping Network Under Uncertainties on Feeder Nodes
detail.abstract: This paper presents an integration of stochastic optimization and Monte Carlo Simulation to address the uncertainties in the extended hub-and-spoke archipelagic network. The network incorporates feeder nodes and routing shipments in the spoke–feeder segment. We also consider wave height uncertainty, which affects cargo handling duration at feeder ports, as observed in a real archipelagic network. Specifically, this involves the enforced use of ship-to-ship (STS) cargo handling in a designated calm area, as opposed to the conventional berthing method in the event of high waves near the jetty. Stochastic optimization is typically used to address this type of problem. However, we found that the stochastic solution provided does not perfectly capture the uncertainty. We thus proposed the integration of stochastic optimization and Monte Carlo simulation, in which a genetic algorithm-based solution is subsequently assessed with a Monte Carlo simulation to generate a risk-optimized solution. A real-world network is used as a case study, showcasing a risk-optimized solution that offers a better likelihood of maintaining performance under uncertainty compared to the solution provided by stochastic optimization. Managerial insight is also derived from the numerical result.

title: Managerial Capital and Adverse Shocks: Evidence from the 2018 Us-China Trade War
affiliations: University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU) - Antai College of Economics and Management

detail.title: Managerial Capital and Adverse Shocks: Evidence from the 2018 Us-China Trade War
detail.abstract: This paper examines how firms respond to adverse tariff shocks by strategically adjusting executive human capital. Leveraging the U.S. China trade war in 2018 as a plausibly exogenous source of negative trade shocks, we find that firms more exposed to the trade shock hire more executives with overseas experience, especially those with marketing expertise and backgrounds in European markets. Consistent with increased demand for such expertise, these executives receive higher compensation following the onset of the trade war, especially through equity-based incentives. We provide suggestive evidence that these executives contribute to maintaining overseas revenue and expanding foreign subsidiaries. Moreover, the stock market responds more negatively to the unexpected departure of such executives during the trade conflict period. Similarly, we document that US firms increased non-Chinese Asia-related representation on their boards. Together, our findings highlight the role of executive human capital in the strategic response of firms to trade shocks.

title: The Causal Effect of Foreign Exchange Intervention Disclosure: Evidence from Japan's Return to Active Intervention
affiliations: Kwansei Gakuin University - Policy Studies, Kwansei Gakuin University and Kwansei Gakuin University

detail.title: The Causal Effect of Foreign Exchange Intervention Disclosure: Evidence from Japan's Return to Active Intervention
detail.abstract: This paper identifies the causal impact of foreign exchange intervention (FXI) disclosure on the yen–dollar exchange rate by exploiting a unique institutional feature in Japan: interventions are disclosed with a two-business-day delay through a rule-based accounting report. Between 2022 and 2024, the Bank of Japan resumed unannounced yen-buying interventions under this delayed disclosure scheme, allowing us to isolate the signaling effect of official confirmation from other simultaneously operating channels. Using high-frequency USD/JPY data and a self-controlled design that compares disclosure days to non-disclosure days, we find that official disclosure leads to a significant appreciation of ¥0.265 per dollar. The effect arises within hours and persists through the day. Market responses reflect the confirmation of intervention rather than surprise about its size, highlighting the role of credibility in FXI effectiveness. Our findings offer a clean identification strategy and underscore how central bank transparency can shape exchange rate dynamics.

title: A Federated Game-Theoretic Strategy for Three-Phase Voltage Unbalance Mitigation Via Dynamic Pricing and Demand Response
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, Tilburg University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: A Federated Game-Theoretic Strategy for Three-Phase Voltage Unbalance Mitigation Via Dynamic Pricing and Demand Response
detail.abstract: This paper introduces a federated game-theoretic framework to mitigate three-phase voltage unbalance in power distribution systems through a fully distributed demand response (DR) program where users act as autonomous agents. Unlike conventional voltage balancing methods that rely on supply-side interventions, the proposed human-centric approach leverages the inherent flexibility of user-side loads across networked buildings to achieve a system-wide three-phase voltage balance, while respecting individual preferences. A mathematical model of user-side grid elements, including various classes of household appliances, energy storage systems (ESS), and distributed energy resources (DER) is developed, advancing the knowledge on how human consumption behaviors can be effectively integrated into power system operations. A novel three-phase dynamic pricing mechanism is designed to incentivize phase-specific consumption adjustments, encouraging users to adopt load patterns that contribute to a balanced three-phase voltage state without compromising comfort preferences. The proposed approach serves as a proof of concept for human-centric design in smart grids, operating entirely on the demand side while being robust, scalable, and privacy-preserving, with low computational complexity for users. Simulations illustrate that strategic load scheduling on each phase, driven by the proposed multi-agent model, significantly improves voltage balance, maintains customer comfort, and supports ancillary services such as peak shaving and frequency regulation.

title: Evolutionary Multi-Task Feature Selection in High-Dimensional Spaces Via Feature Association Graph
affiliations: Jiangsu University, Jiangsu University, Jiangsu University of Science and Technology, affiliation not provided to SSRN and Department of Computer Science, School of Engineering & Computer Science, Baylor University

detail.title: Evolutionary Multi-Task Feature Selection in High-Dimensional Spaces Via Feature Association Graph
detail.abstract: Evolutionary Multi-Task (EMT) paradigm, an emerging and promising approach in evolutionary computation, demonstrates strong potential for solving high-dimensional feature selection (FS) problems. However, existing EMT-based FS methods are often constrained by limitations such as homogeneous task generation relying on single filtering strategies and inadequate modeling of complex feature dependencies. Hence, a novel Evolutionary Multi-Task Feature Selection framework using Feature Association Graph (EMT-FAG) is proposed. Within this framework, three interrelated tasks are designed: one focusing on promising features, another exploring the entire feature space, and a third leveraging a dynamic feature association graph to capture and model complex feature interactions. A knowledge transfer mechanism is introduced, enabling efficient inter-task information sharing through particle swarm optimization, which improves optimization efficiency and mitigates premature convergence. This paper also proposes a dual-information fusion filtering method that comprehensively evaluates feature importance by integrating multiple metrics, providing a more robust and comprehensive evaluation framework for high-dimensional feature selection. The proposed framework is extensively validated through experiments on sixteen high-dimensional datasets, and the results demonstrate that EMT-FAG achieves similar or superior performance to state-of-the-art FS algorithms.

title: The Impact of Non-R&D Innovation Activities on Firm Productivity: The Case of Turkiye
affiliations: Ankara Haci Bayram Veli University, Ankara Haci Bayram Veli University and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: The Impact of Non-R&D Innovation Activities on Firm Productivity: The Case of Turkiye
detail.abstract: This study examines the impact of non-R&D innovation activities on firm productivity in the context of an emerging economy—Turkiye—where such activities constitute the predominant innovation strategy. While most empirical research and policy frameworks emphasize R&D-driven innovation, a growing body of evidence suggests that non-R&D activities—such as organizational changes, marketing strategies, and technology acquisition—play a critical role, particularly in countries with limited R&D capacity. Using firm-level microdata from three consecutive waves (2016–2018, 2018–2020, and 2020–2022) of the Turkish Community Innovation Survey (CIS), the analysis employs a three-stage structural modeling approach: (i) the firm’s decision to engage in non-R&D innovation and the intensity of such investments, estimated using a generalized Tobit model; (ii) the conversion of these investments into non-technological innovation outputs, analyzed through an instrumented probit model; and (iii) the effect of these outputs on labor productivity, proxied by the logarithm of sales per employee. The results indicate a robust and statistically significant effect of non-R&D investment intensity on non-technological innovation outcomes, with particularly strong effects observed during the 2018–2020 period. Moreover, both non-technological innovation and the direct intensity of non-R&D investments are found to enhance firm productivity, with non-R&D intensity exerting a direct effect even after controlling for innovation outputs. These findings underscore the critical role of non-R&D innovation in boosting productivity in developing economies with constrained R&D capacity, thereby addressing the limitations of R&D-centric models.

title: Gender Gap in Returns to Publications
affiliations: Zayed University, Polish Academy of Sciences and University of Birmingham

detail.title: Gender Gap in Returns to Publications
detail.abstract: We examine gender gaps in pay, attribution, and monetary returns to research productivity across major academic disciplines using a novel dataset combining salary information and publication records for professors at U.S. public universities. Our results suggest an unconditional gender pay gap of $24,059 per year, representing a 15.9% difference relative to male earnings, with substantial variation across disciplines, from 5.5% in agricultural sciences to 20.9% in social sciences. After controlling for experience, academic fields, and research productivity, a pay gap of 4.4% remains unexplained, suggesting potential discrimination. We also uncover a distinct gender gap in attribution: female faculty receive lower compensation compared to male peers for co-authored publications, whereas solo-authored publications by women consistently yield positive returns. Finally, there is no significant gender gap in monetary returns to publications— a novel contribution that has not been addressed in existing research.

title: Sovereign Debt Auctions with Strategic Interactions
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Johns Hopkins University

detail.title: Sovereign Debt Auctions with Strategic Interactions

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: In this paper, we build a model of sovereign borrowing and default, disciplined with proprietary bid level data, to study the impact that alternative ways of issuing sovereign debt have on borrowing decisions, the cost of debt, and welfare. We focus on the two most common types of auctions used for sovereign debt issuances: uniform and discriminatory price auctions. We calibrate the model to the Portuguese economy and find that the type of auction used has quantitative implications. In particular, discriminatory auctions generate spreads that provide a better fit to the data. In a counterfactual, we find that switching to a uniform protocol constitutes a Pareto improvement, and that the difference in welfare is highest during crises (0.6 percent of permanent consumption). Finally, we find that accounting for dynamic effects is crucial. In a single auction setting, a risk averse government prefers the discriminatory protocol. However, with repeated auctions, the properties of the discriminatory protocol incentivize over-borrowing. The anticipatory effect it has on prices makes the uniform protocol a better option.

title: Options for Strengthening Ireland's Fiscal Framework
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF), International Monetary Fund (IMF), International Monetary Fund (IMF) and Princeton University

detail.title: Options for Strengthening Ireland's Fiscal Framework

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Ireland’s reliance on corporate income tax (CIT) receipts from multinational enterprises, concentrated in a small number of companies, presents significant risks to the budget. The uncertain nature of this revenue calls for a robust fiscal framework to safeguard public finances. This paper proposes strengthening the national fiscal framework by establishing a prudent medium-term debt anchor and an expenditure rule to guide the annual budget process. We first establish a prudent debt anchor for Ireland by calibrating CIT shocks and simulating possible debt trajectories. Second, we propose an operational rule based on multi-year expenditure ceilings. The ceilings are calibrated such as to stabilize debt at the anchor level while accounting for the economy’s cyclical position. Although tailored to Ireland, the methodology employed has broader applicability for designing effective fiscal rules.

title: Building Macroeconomic Resilience to Natural Disasters and Persistent Temperature Changes
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Building Macroeconomic Resilience to Natural Disasters and Persistent Temperature Changes

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: Peru is highly exposed to periodic El Niño Costero events, which impair production in the country’s fishing, agriculture, and construction sectors, as well as inflict sizeable damages to physical assets. Moreover, rising average temperatures are expected to diminish productivity in agriculture, fisheries, and energy. Without efforts to strengthen its adaptive capacity, the country remains highly vulnerable to such acute and chronic physical risks in the long term. This paper combines a Markov-switching DSGE model with empirical estimates of losses from such risks to conduct a scenario analysis of their macro-fiscal implications. We find that cumulative income losses could reach up to 18.6 percent by 2050 and 50.6 percent by 2100. The analysis further shows that scaling up investments in structural resilience and adaptation can partially mitigate these losses—raising output by up to 12.3 percent by 2050 and 31 percent by 2100—while also generating long-term fiscal savings.

title: Monetary Policy Transmission to Lending Rates
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF) and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Monetary Policy Transmission to Lending Rates

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper estimates the strength of monetary policy transmission to bank lending rates in Brazil. We identify monetary policy shocks using forecast errors from Brazi’s daily Focus survey of professional forecasters. We then estimate the pass-through to lending rates based on an instrumental variable application of local projections and find an aggregate pass-through of 70 percent after four months, reflecting full passthrough to market-based lending rates and 20 percent to government-directed credit interest rates. Analysis using bank-level data reveals varying degrees of pass-through across credit types, from 40 percent for payrollbacked loans to 80 percent for working capital loans, and stronger pass-through for larger banks. Estimated pass-through has increased since 2020 due to more responsive corporate loans

title: Money Market Fund Growth During Hiking Cycles
affiliations: International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Money Market Fund Growth During Hiking Cycles

publicationDetails.journalName: International Monetary Fund (IMF) Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This paper examines the drivers of money market funds (MMFs) growth during monetary policy hiking cycles. Analyzing data from nine countries with notable MMF sectors post-pandemic, it examines three main drivers: yield differentials between MMFs and bank deposits, banking turmoils that affect perceptions of relative safety for traditional cash options, and structural characteristics (types) of MMFs. The findings indicate that MMFs attract capital during rising interest rates driven primarily by yield-seeking behavior. This pattern persisted following the 2023 banking turmoil, particularly in the U.S., where yield remained the dominant driver. After accounting for yield differentials, MMF growth was not unusually high compared to previous hiking cycles, suggesting limited evidence of widespread flight-to-safety flows. Moreover, when MMF yields rise, investors in the US and the euro area increasingly favor private debt MMFs, likely due to their higher yields. The study underscores the trade-off between safety and yield in investor behaviour, providing insights for policymakers on enhancing financial stability.
